Why you should consider buying this phone, and what the reviewers fail to mention.
This is a fantastic phone
I bought this phone before it became available on Amazon at Best Buy, but I thought potential buyers would be interested in these attributes of the Samsung 21 FE
Positives (in no particular order):1) Excellent camera
It takes night pictures with a quality that is almost beyond belief
I was able to capture an image that had stars visible in the image
I've never had that on a cell phone
The daytime images are comparable to the iPhone 13, which are quite good
Something the reviewers fail to mention with the camera is the Field of View, which is 79 degrees, or equivalent to around 26

5 mm, full frame, which is just a tad narrower than the iPhone 13, and quite a bit narrower than the s21 ultra which is around 24 mm, and the s22 ultra which is reported at coming in at 23 mm, with a FOV of 86 degrees
This is not acceptable as this will lead to significant distortion when taking pictures of people at closer range with the main camera
It may be possible to correct through algorithms using the AI, but the subjects will always be smaller
The Snapdragon (SD) 888 was know to run hot, and the SD 8 Gen 1 is even hotter
Most people do not need that type of bleeding edge of performance
I've seen conflicting reviews concerning battery life
Not to mention, most content is still 16:9, which is more enjoyable to use on this aspect ratio
Very few reviewers will cover this
The S20 FE will only have till Android 13 and 1 year of security updates beyond this
This phone is not perfect, though, as indicated below:1) Weak haptic motor
I'm not sure how relevant this is as 90% of people buying this phone will put a case on it, myself included
Many compare it to the Pixel 6
In addition, the signal reception has been found to be lacking in the Pixel 6
A phone, no matter how well spec'd, is useless without a good signal
This is a disappointing thing for many, myself included, but the positive attributes outweigh this

This SAMSUNG Galaxy S20 FE 5G was not my first choice, but since LG has stopped manufacturing phones, it was my second choice
Replacing my LG Style 6, which measures over 7, this Samsung phone is smaller but still comfortable to use in most regards
Most phones I and my wife have had these past several years have their fingerprint reader on the back of the phone, which is much easier to use and more comfortable
The Samsung S20 FE has a fingerprint reader embedded on the bottom of the screen, which is a bit awkward to use
But the fingerprint reader is fairly accurate providing you follow the directions and scan multiple areas of your fingertip
The screen is vibrant with deep colors & good contrast
Since my phone is primarly a phone that I occasionally use for texting, I haven't used the camera yet nor do I use all of the features associated with video
I have my dozen or so apps that I use frequently, and they all work well on this phone
There isn't much bloatware installed by Samsung; most of it is installed by Google
I do seem to get a bit better connection with this phone

Do not buy this phone.  As far as I am concerned this phone is a complete piece of trash.
The phone works well as a phone, past the 5G switching not being completely worked out, but that is a carrier issue
I am a Sprint customer and because of the merger and network confusion my phone thinks a 5/5 Sprint 4G LTE signal isroaming and tried to grab the 1 bar TMobile signal
Now for the showstopper
The touch hardware is complete and utter trash
The October firmware update helped a bit
The sensor array is in a horizontal/Vertical grid
If you touch three points on the screen and slide any of those fingers past the same grid line as another finger, it drops the moving touch
I used developer mode to show touches and can watch the touch just disappear
Now if I place two fingers on each side of the screen so they're both on the same horizontal plane, and then move a third finger between them it drops touch and then strobes every single time
This really looks like an issue from the early days when companies were struggling to get multi finger gestures to reliably work
Perhaps Samsung used a design made in 2006-2008 to maximize profits
I pre-ordered this phone
That's your thing
And then you decided to sell it anyway
This is my third Galaxy S10 FE with this same issue

Initial phone was Sprint branded (returned), second was unlocked (waited two weeks for more information and spent over an hour on the phone with Samsung, the Requested replacement), replacement phone has same exact issue

I replaced an older LG G8 and this is my first Samsung phone since the original Galaxy (which I was horrible for me)
I bought this because it supports an SD Card and was otherwise a relatively inexpensive, yet full featured phone
If I have one notable complaint, it's how the camera physically protrudes from the phone
Not much, but it prevents it from sitting flat on a surface (unless I have it in a case)
This might be necessary for the camera's features and the thinness of the phone, but it makes me concerned about scratching the camera glass
While there are glass screen protectors for the camera glass, they don't stay on well unless appropriately protected in a case
Overall very good, but I don't like how the phone makes me concerned about damaging the camera area and doesn't otherwise sit flat outside of a case

I was so excited to get my Galaxy S20 FE phone as it was an upgrade from the S8 I've had for years
I purchased the US version Unlocked and took it to my local US Cellular store to have a clerk switch everything from my S8 to the S20
I was told by the clerk after she attempted to get the phone registered and set up with US Cellular that the phone was not compatible with the network

According to the Amazon add this phone is supposed to be compatible with US Cellular so I do not know if I was getting a line of BS from the US Cellular clerk because I didn't purchase the phone through them (even though they no longer carry the S20 FE) or if it's false advertisement on Amazon (hence the 2 star rating)
I was so livid yesterday after leaving the US Cellular store that I just went home, started the return process to send this phone back to Amazon, boxed it up and dropped it off at the local UPS Store
If I want to upgrade my phone I guess I'm stuck with purchasing a phone through US Cellular so I know it will work
I'm looking at the Galaxy A52 as it's similar in price to the Cloud Navy S20FE that I purchased through Amazon

I currently have a Galaxy Note 10 and before that the Pixel 3
The Note 20 has been great but I've been wanting to upgrade to something with a better battery
I've tried the Note 20 Ultra (too big and bulky) and the Note 20 (not worth $999 or even $799) and finally arrived at the S20 FE
So far, the battery life has been great with 6-7 hours screen on time
Compared to the Note line and pretty much everything else in the marketplace right now, this is a fantastic device at this price point
The screen is as good as the Note 20 line with its great color accuracy, sharpness and bright screen
While it doesn't have WQHD+ like the Note 20 Ultra, it does have 120hz which the Note 20 doesn't
So if you're running 120hz, you can't use WQHD+ anyway
This device also has a fantastic camera system that takes better shots than the Note 20
I've compared them side by side and the S20 FE delivers more vibrant and sharper images
While the telephoto is only 8MP, it didn't seem to effect the quality and outputs pictures that were just as good as the Note 20
The Note 20 Ultra has an amazing telephoto, so if that's important to you, then go for it, but costing about $500 more than this device, seems not worth it
If you're a Pixel user, One UI is an adjustment but I actually enjoy it with all the options it brings

Samsung has also been great about doing monthly updates and will be giving 3 years OS support on the S20 FEI do wish it came with 8GB instead of 6 but I haven't noticed any performance issues as a result - the device feels just as fast and fluid as the other more expensive phones I tried with much more RAM
Perhaps if you're a gamer or heavy multi-tasker, this might be a bigger factor to consider in your decision to buy this device
I've seen comments about the finger print scanner being unreliable but I haven't experienced that at all
In fact, it's been much more reliable and way faster than sonic ones in the newer Note 20 devices I tried

If you're considering this over the Pixel 5, the S20 FE seems the better value with better CPU, 120hz screen and more versatile camera system (but the Pixel will undoubtedly take better pictures as its the camera king!), expandable storage, bigger battery and faster charging
If you're considering this over the Note 20 (standard not Ultra), the S20 FE is a much better value for less money giving you 120hz screen, expandable storage and better camera
Unfortunately you lose out on the S-Pen with the S20 FE, but if you can go without, then the S20 FE is a much bigger bang for your buck
At the end of the day, I think this phone is a superb value at $599 and the best you can get at this price point

I was prepared to purchase a 25W charger, but after experiencing the bundled 15W, I sense that 5V 3A is nice balance between faster and cooler operation that will probably prolong the working life of the battery
Similarly for the Qi wireless charging which is naturally inefficient and runs even hotter
I am shopping for aftermarket chargers, but no hurry
The set of bundled apps is unsettling and in need of attention
A first clue was when calendar did not sync properly
Turns out that Samsung has an entire set of unbranded applications spoofing basic Google apps including:phone, calendar, contacts, my files, clock, gallery, messages, and more
What is unsettling is that these Samsung apps are UNBRANDED presumably to lull consumers into believing they are Google branded apps
It seems this required many gatekeeper failures including but not limited to:Google App certification approved a set ofunbranded apps to exist
The trickery continues with unbranded notifications with no explicit indication which app is requesting access to personal information

For example, is enabling Find My Phone a prompt from Samsung, Google, the data provider, and/or some other entity?There are also unbranded notifications that appear from hidden Apps that are not readily located such as Carrier Hub
Some permissions such as Bixby cannot be changed
Another sloppy mistake was a terms and conditions click to agree screen that was missing the actual terms and conditions statements
Surely the EU, California CCPA, and other laws prohibit such deception
The out of the box experience can be daunting
Many steps and insider knowledge are required just to turn on and configure the phone
Setup can be never-ending

Each time you want to turn on the phone:you have to pick up the phone, tap twice, wait for facial recognition to fail, swipe up, enter password, swipe up to get to a home button, hit home, then navigate to where you want to be
Shipping an obsolete version of Android is disappointing and let's just say there is some opportunity for software updates to improve

Samsung Galaxy S20 FE – 18 Months Later
The S20FE, redefined what it meant to be a budget flagship, and a premium mid-range device
5 inch AMOLED display- Under-Display fingerprint sensor- 4500 MAH battery- Gorilla Glass 3 on the front display
Odds and Ends:- Touch Sensitivity: When the device first came out in 2020 there were reports of touch sensitivity problems and instances of ghost touches
Great with a few flaws
I wanted to love this phone
Too be fair, if you don't need or use your phone in outdoor lighting, this thing is great otherwise
Great phone for the price
For $600, I would say this is a pretty good phone for the price
Battery life - The S20 FE lasts a full day easily even with 120hz turned on
Back cameras - The back cameras are a big upgrade from my previous Note 8
Flat screen - As someone who quickly got annoyed with the curved edges on my old Note 8 rendering it unusable without a case, the S20 FE's flat screen is a nice change
Size - I love big phones, and I love big screens even more
5-inch display is great, and the phone is about the same size as my Note 8, which has a smaller display
Front camera quality - While the back cameras are impressive, the front camera is less so
Touchscreen issues - I have had touchscreen issues where instead of scrolling the screen will randomly register it as clicks instead
Buttons - I am fine with Samsung moving the volume buttons to the right side
Edit - July 2021 Update:Been using the same phone still since September of 2020

I am offering this review after owning the Galaxy S10E for about 1 year
I got this phone after I dropped my Moto X in water and I chose the Galaxy because I have a Galaxy watch and they two are supposed to work best together
I don't particularly have any complaints about the phone, it makes and receives calls
It has reasonable storage

The Moto X have functions to turn on the flashlight (shake the phone) and camera (twist the phone) that I still missIn fact, when I DO need the flashlight, I find it very cumbersome to turn on as it is a button on the pull-down settings menu
This does work, however, you have to lay the watch on the BACK of the phone - perfectly centered and STILL
I've had the phone in an Otterbox case the whole time I've had it and when I did need this powershare function, I had to take the phone out of the case
The screen got scratched all to pieces the one time I tried to do this - when I went on a short trip and forgot my watch charger
It is a small phone - I don't have complaints about the screen per se, but when I hold it out of the case I feel like it might slip through my hands easily
I have dropped it a number of times - in that Otterbox case - and it has never cracked or failed in any way
I've mentioned the case a couple of times so I do want to make a disclaimer - I won't buy another Otter Box case - it is supposed to have a lifetime warranty and the corner of it is broken off

I did say that I've dropped the phone, but that corner fell off at the strangest time - in fact, I got into my car and there was a piece of blue plastic lying on my black seat after looking all around, I realized it had come off my phone case
That doesn't seem like much of a warranty to me

Buttons Fall Off, Samsung Customer Support Unhelpful
I purchased this phone from Amazon in November 2020
In most ways it's an excellent product
However after 6 months of routine use the POWER button fell out of the phone

I searched online and discovered this was a common problem, but I imagined it would be a simple repairI brought the phone to a Samsung Authorized Service Center which told me that:1) Loss of the POWER button was considered “cosmetic” damage by Samsung and would not be covered under the 1 year warranty2) The POWER button is integrated with the display and cannot be replaced independently
So in order to fix the button I would have to pay for a new screen

I phoned Samsung customer service and they repeated the same explanation, but offered that I had the option of bringing the phone to a Samsung owned service center (a 90 minute drive each way) where they would inspect the phone and if the loss of the button was deemed a manufacturing problem then the replacement would be free
Otherwise I would have face the same charge for screen replacement and I would have wasted half a day getting there and back
It's extremely disappointing that the only frequently used moving parts on this otherwise fine product are engineered with such flimsy plastic
It's extremely disappointing that Samsung does not accept any responsibility for the design problem
Any customers who buy the phone based on its otherwise good performance and value should exercise great care when pressing the POWER and VOLUME buttons to avoid unwelcome repair expense

First things first:it has no headphone jack
Every phone should have a headphone jack
Leaving this out was an extremely stupid decision when Apple made it, and an even dumber one when Samsung followed their lead
If you're going to use a phone in public (as most cellphone users do sometimes!), it's a pretty basic piece of functionality to be able to do that without disturbing those around you
The official line is that leaving it out left room for a bigger battery, but there's a huge amount of space taken up by the multiple cameras
Leaving one of those off would have left enough room to include a jack
The description says it charges in minutes, and technically that's true; 200 is a number of minutes
My S8 Active that the back has almost fallen off charges faster
It's at least easy to set the side button to do something useful now, instead of summoning Bixby; that saves it from a 1-star review

In 1982, first cellular I tested was bolted to my car
March 6, 2021: Started testing my 2nd 5G phone: Pixel 4a 5G
Here's what I've learned so far:PROS:1
Pixel 4A 5G & VZW 5G Band
Just got this phone a few days ago, so still evaluating it but wanted to clarify one point that some users are having a different experience with-the 5G functionality with VZW
I've attached a photo showing that the 4A 5G that I received from Amazon DOES work with VZW's 5G band
Just wanted to get that point out here on the reviews, based on what I had read here I was ready to handle just a 4G connection, so I'm excited to see that 5G icon!So far, love this unit
I've always been a pixel fan, except for the pixel 4 and it's huge forehead and chin, seemed to go opposite of the smartphone trends
Say what you want about a plastic build, but I love it
It's so light
And what's is the big draw to a glass back build?Glass breaks people, plastic doesn't
And have fun paying for that glass replacement, since none of the phone insurance plans will cover it
And what do 99 % of us do with our glass sandwiches???Slap a rubber or plastic case on it
I'd rather have the plastic build, yes with a case, but the weight is so much less since it isn't wrapped in glass
Big proponent of the pure google experience on the pixel series and no overlaid UI from the manufacturer
Battery life on this one is good
Started out at 830 this morning and at 1900 was at 45%
Plenty of screen time during the day
So no complaints there
Speakers are incredible
Any time you have to turn the volume down on a phone cause the sound effects are blowing you away on that game or movie, is a sign of a great set of speakers
Charge time is fine
Not as fast as some of the flagships, but I've been able to go from 25% to 68% in 20 minutes
That's good enough for me, and I'm rarely away from a plug or a battery pack, so charge time isn't a huge factor for me
The fingerprint reader is what we've come to expect on the pixel -Faster than lightning
The in screen readers on the flagships are just no where near as reliable or fast
I'll have to get used to the rear mount again, but that's not a problem for me
If you need face recognition or wireless charging then this isn't the device for you obviously
But I don't list that as a kick in the nuts to the pixel 4A 5G, it just doesn't have it, so if you need those options then look elsewhere
For my money, 459 for this phone is an awesome deal
This will be my daily driver for the near future, for sure
Google/Amazon = Censorship... and the phone kind of sucks

Will be returning this because:
a
The phone itself is kind of cheaply made; feels flimsy
@459 I feel it's a solid value
I use multiple phones, and I'm multi-platform, so if you ask me:Which are you, an android, iphone, mac, windows, or linux user?My answer is:yesBut I've never paid over $1000 for a phone
I like flagship phones though, and will buy a new-old-stock, or pristine used, 2 year old flagship model

With iPhone this is standard
With android phone makers, it's hit and miss, mostly miss
Samsung does update their flagship frequently
But Samsung wants $1200 for their flagship
Their phones don't cost $1000
Saw some good things said about the Pixel, thought I'd try the Pixel 4a 5G and see if I liked it
I don't have complex needs
Other than good security, and frequent security updates, I also like good pictures and video
The phone is light, the battery lasts a long time, the screen is just a little bit smaller than my iPhone 8 Plus and far lighter
The iPhone 8 Plus was a flagship at one time, and you can tell
The build quality is phenomenol
It's also heavy, feels expensive, and the feature set and ecosphere quite complete
Almost heavy-ish
I love the phone, and it's my backup now
The Pixel 4a 5G is minimalist, light, leaves you uninvolved or slightly detached from the massive Google ecosphere, unless you go in and configure the various bits and pieces of it
I'm very pleased with my purchase
Refreshing alternative to Samsung
Don't get me wrong, Samsung flagship is a beast
But I never buy new $1000 plus phones
So the best that I could do is buy a used or NOS Samsung Note, which I did (a Note 9), and it was a terrible experience
Old android version, build quality was not too hot
If you ever look at buying a flagship phone that is 2 or 3 versons behind, Samsung can't cut it
Apple is much better in that scenario
But I'm glad that there's something that fills the gap between flagship phones, and just a nice, new, current, phone with frequent updates
Who better to get an android device from, then the people who make android?
Exactly What I Wanted
I needed a replacement for my Samsung Galaxy s4 I bought in 2014
The Samsung phone still worked but with Android 5 most apps would not run on it
Also I was getting so many spam calls here in Las Vegas that it was driving me crazy
First priority I wanted a phone that would screen calls for me
None of the call blocker apps worked well enough for me and I did not want to pay extra charges for some premium app
When I heard that Google had a built in call screener, I decided I had to get a Pixel phone
Next I wanted a phone that would stay current with software updates as long as possible because I intend to keep it forever
Google guarantees three years worth of updates which is the longest I could find
So I had to getPixel phone
Finally I wanted a phone with a big enough screen that i could read it easily as I am over 70 and my eyes aren't what they used to be
This is why I picked the Pixel 4a with 5G instead of the Pixel 4a
I didn't care about waterproofing or wireless charging, etc
I got my phone from Amazon in early December after waiting for Prime day and Black Friday and being disappointed that there were no discounts
If I had waited a bit longer i could have gotten $50 off, but that's life
I've had the phone now for around three months and it works well
I LOVE the call screener,It comes with Android 11 and should be good at least through Android 14
The size is just right and it is much faster than my old S4 and runs all the apps I will ever use
I don't make many calls so one charge lasts almost 4 days
It charges completely from almost zero to 100% in about an hour and a half - much faster than my S4
The only weak point is that occasionally the fingerprint reader takes several tries to work
I signed up with T-Mobile on their $15/mo plan and the connections I get around Vegas are superb
Often I get a 5G connection and I have yet to have a dropped call
I rarely use data outside my home so 2GB/mo is plenty for my use
I rarely use the camera
Bottom line is I am very happy with this phone
I expect to keep it for many, many years
Love it. Nice phone worth every penny.

I've been on the market for a new phone wanted something with large memory capacity and awesome camera system without paying a high price tag for it so I stumbled across the pixel 4a 5g I've always been an Android girl so wanted to stick with what I know this phone is very nice fits in my hands well good size and weight

I got new hearing aids whose controlling app required a version of Android newer than Oreo on my favored but ancient LG V20
So I wanted a new phone that would support the app plus 5G plus a 3
the 4a 5G fit the bill and I have been very happy with it
I had live translate on my old phone that let me hear what the tour leader was saying while on the bus and it is still there
But in addition there is live captioning that translates audiobooks, videos, calls etc in real time
I also prefer the fingerprint reader because I have doubts that face-recognition would would with covid masks
The battery is a little under-powered (I had a 10,000 mah monster for the V20 which had easily replaceable batteries) but it picks up quite a bit of charge in a few minutes

The phone is solid, it does everything I would expect, it replaced my Pixel XL and for the most part I am happy with the phone

The 5G you will get on carriers other than Verizon is called Sub-6GHZ, and while speeds and coverage are better, it seems like the industry is boasting of it's mmWave service in their advertising and I think this is what most are expecting when they here 5g

Does this matter much today? No, most people don't get a mmWave signal, I had to call ATT to find the nearest one to me and it is over 1500 feet away, which is the about how far an mmWave signal can reach, assuming no obstructions
This is not meant to cast a negative light on the phone, just to give realistic expectation if you get one

I bought the Pixel 4a (5g) in October 2021 from Amazon
But I am very disappointed in my Amazon purchase -- and it's way too late to return
A Thin, Light, Feature-Packed Phone That's Easily Destroyed!

The Google Pixel 4A 5G truly sounds impressive on paper with its Night Vision mode, powerful videography capabilities, 5G connectivity, extensive suite of apps, large file storage capacity, all-day battery, video streaming, yadda yadda yadda
And it's THIN!And it's LIGHT! - Only 168 grams!There's only one problem, however
It is as fragile as a potato chip
Six days ago, I was walking through my neighborhood with my nine-month-old Google Pixel 4A 5G in my front right pants pocket
The Pixel was encased in a Spigen Tough Armor case and was equipped with a tempered glass screen protector
Due to an unfortunate encounter with a dog, I tripped and fell - on my back, mind you

I was fortunately not hurt (although to this day I hope that worthless dog gets struck by lightning), but when I pulled my Pixel out of my pocket to exchange phone numbers with the dog's owner, I discovered the damage you see in the attached pictures
The phone display showed what I can only describe as a green screen of death
From that moment to now, the phone has been totally unusable
The front screen is destroyed, the headphone jack is destroyed, and the back cover has partially separated from the front of the phone
And all this from a drop of about 33 inches
And if I want to take pictures, there are plenty of good cameras that I can buy
My Pixel's capabilities are worthless to me now, and I am out $500 dollars for a phone that's turned into a piece of junk

It's not like we're competing in the summer Olympics!I am thinking right now of the Greek myth of Sisyphus being punished eternally by being forced to roll a large boulder up a hill only to have the boulder slip out of his hands just before he gets to the hilltop

And I can imagine someone coming to him and saying, Dude - the reason you can't roll that rock over the hill is because of the smartphone you're carrying!It adds weight and slows you down!You should buy one of our phones, because they don't weigh anything more than air!Thin + light does not always equal cutting-edge quality
Thin + light = cheap sometimes

Not officially supported by AT&T -- text/data/voice may not work in your area
I received this phone on 9/15 and it did not work properly with my AT&T SIM card

After two days of talking to four different AT&T technical support representatives, on 9/16 they told me that this phone is not supported by AT&T and isn't compatible with the new 5G network that they are rolling out
I believe this is because some cell towers have been upgraded to the new network (4G/5G only) which don't support this phone, while others still use the old 3G network hardware
So the statement in the product description works with AT&T is not totally accurate, as it may not work at all for you

Great Phone
Bottom line: This is a great phone
I am migrating from a Samsung S10
I would say this phone is on par with that or slightly superior
It’s not hard, but definitely different swipes and buttons
Just take the on-board tutorials and it gets you in the groove fast
CPU and memory:This is a speedy phone and works quickly with no lags or freezes
Seamless with Google: Since this is made and updated by Google, the phone can be tweaked perfectly to make use of any Android or Google feature you want
This is the first Google brand phone I’ve owned and I was surprised how much of Google “tracking” you can turn off
As with any Android smart phone, it can all be customized and honed just the way you like it
Software and Security Updates:Updates are frequent and timely
This is important to me, as there seems to be ongoing vulnerabilities with all phones and software (even iPhones)
This phone is noticeably quicker to “fix” stuff than Samsung
It has many positives, but the night mode is especially impressive
-No wireless charging (but I never used that anyway because it heats the battery up too much and limits its life)
-The fingerprint unlock is hit or miss, but I think that might be me (user error)
Great phone, big upgrade to the Pixel 3 XL
So to start this off: Yes 5G is fast, much faster than 4G
To get it out of the way: Yes the phone does have an audio jack so you can plug your headphones into it
The power and volume buttons are very easy to distinguish from one another
The biggest thing I noticed with this Pixel is the screen brightness is top notch
The camera is really good
The fingerprint reader on this phone is very good
The phone does not have the water resistance of the more expensive models
The phone is wonderful so far
The battery life is AMAZING
The biggest issue I have had with it, and this may be my fingers only, but the outside ring of the screen is not as sensitive as the inside of it
Overall this is a great phone
Another fabulous Pixel phone - with tremendous battery life

Google Pixel 4a with 5G - Android Phone - New Unlocked Smartphone with Night Sight and Ultrawide Lens - Just BlackWe ordered this for my husband, whose first words upon using it were to comment on how fast it is
There is a size difference between the two and he was concerned he'd find it an issue
But he'd give up the extra size in a second for the phenomenal battery life on this one

He is running it on Verizon, which supposedly does not support the 5G, but it does slip into 5g mode now and then
The only thing that is different - and significantly so, to him - is that there is NOT wireless charging on this device
He used wireless charging with the 3xl and loved it
It's a fabulous phone though and he's very happy with it
OMG

A great value for a 5G Android phone
This is my first Google phone, but my 4th Android phone
I use my iPhone as my primary personal phone, but I use Android phones for my business
I ordered this new Pixel 4a with 5G phone to replace an older Samsung phone that does not support 5G
Since T-Mobile supports 5G in my area, I wanted both of my primary phones to be able to take advantage of the higher speed
I have never used the regular Pixel 4a, but the 4a with 5G is a much nicer phone
It has 2 cameras vs 1 in the regular 4a, it has a larger battery, it has a larger screen, and the processor is much faster (The same processor as the Pixel 5)
Among 5G phones, this is definitely one of the least expensive models on the market
Although the processor is still much slower than the A14 in my iPhone 12 Pro Max, I can't tell that from using the phone
Everything I do is very fast, and the quality of the photos is excellent
It is hard to tell the difference between the photos I take with the Pixel vs the ones I take with my iPhone
In order to keep the price down, Google did not make the phone waterproof, so don't drop it in the bathtub!Also, it does not support wireless charging
But for under $500, this is the phone to get if you are an Android user

And because the phone is made by Google (the same company that makes the Android operating system), you can expect that it will support upgrades to newer versions of Android for longer than most other brands of Android phones, and also that those upgrades will be available sooner
excellent value for a midrange phone
The Google Pixel 4a with 5G is a great midrange phone
It's not as stunning visually as top of the line phones, but after a month of use, I can say it does everything I need
It's unlocked, it doesn't come loaded with bloatware, it's fast, sturdy, reliable, charges quickly, and has excellent battery life
I like that it has a headphone jack (sometimes eliminated on smartphones now) and the camera works well even in low light

Minor potential drawbacks are:(1) it has a plastic body and its appearance is more practical/unobtrusive/functional than flashy or pretty(2) no water resistance(3) no MicroSD card slot(4) no facial recognition, but due to privacy concerns I don't want this anyway
It does have a fingerprint reader
I don't particularly care about any of that (well, except for the superficial visual/design aspect, a little), so the Pixel 4a is a good fit for what I want
Compared to the regular Pixel 4A, the Pixel 4A 5G has a larger display, an additional camera, 5G connectivity, and the processor is just a little faster
It can also take Night Sight portraits and it has 3 video stabilization modes
YMMV on whether you think those features are worth the additional $150

Google Pixel 4a with 5G - Android Phone - New Unlocked Smartphone with Night Sight and Ultrawide Lens - Just BlackAs a lifetime iPhone user, I was kind of nervous about taking the leap and switching to Android
To make this review easier, I’ll split up my likes and dislikes
The good:- Decent processing speed, noticeably better than my old iPhone
The eh to bad:- Honestly, apps on Android just aren’t as good as on IOS
-Missing a lot of features that recent phones have adopted, like facial recognition, wireless charging
I think this is a solid choice for a mid-priced phone
Battery Life Is Great Compared To My Old iPhone 6s
I got this phone to replace my daughters iPhone 6s
The screen was cracked and it was older so I wanted to upgrade what she was able to do
While she was not familiar with the Android operating system she was able to adapt
At 16 years old I need her to have a phone so that I can get ahold of her when she goes out with her friends and such
Here were her thoughts on the phone
The transfer from my iPhone was the easiest transfer I have ever done
It only took about 20 minutes and I used the cord that came with the phone
I had used up 100% of the space on my old iPhone and it still only took 20 minutes total
It even transferred things like my alarms
I was dreading transferring all 16 different alarms I had set for different things throughout each weeks so this was awesome
It did not transfer things like group chats from iMessages so I did miss a few class things until I got that set back up
Google Duo has replaced my need for FaceTime and I actually like the interface and clarity a lot better
The phone is much faster and streaming videos or Zoom chats for class is much clearer with no glitching
It was also able to take the SIM card from my old iPhone so no need to set up the phone through my carrier
The camera is amazing and all my pictures are so much clearer
The interface for photo editing is my favorite feature and much better than what I was used too
Overall this is a great phone and the features were easy to understand and change to
Can't go wrong

That is what they call adaptive charging
Instead of a toggle that lets you charge the phone quickly or slowly (for better battery life), you have to set an alarm and then it will charge slowly, finishing before the alarm

I bought the Pixel 4a 5G for 3 reasons:1
I didn't think the camera was that great at first but it's been taking really good pictures, it's grown on me and I haven't used all the features yet
Let me compare it to the iPhone
I have small children
The iPhone is a better camera option for a parent for 1 reason - live photos
I often have to edit pictures to get a usable photo
The Pixel wins for its automatic picture quality and software but the iPhone wins because of its live features; and I really liked the Portrait mode on the XS when it worked
I plan to keep it for a few years and it has 5G
The 5G capability will make it usable in 4-5 years
The phone will be updated to Android 14 and it will stay modern for a while
It's not stock Android on the phone, it's Android with extra Google features exclusive to Pixel phones

The LG has a 32 bit DAC and the dual screen is nice

7 and a MacBook as well

It has a minor issue that oneplus could improve upon
I miss having an always on display
The oneplus 8 has kind of a half-azzed version of that
The display will light up for notifications, but only the instant you get them, then the screen returns to darkness
That is nearly useless since I'm not staring at my phone constantly
There's also no indicator light to let you know you've gotten notifications
So basically when you get a notification of any kind, the phone's half on display flashes for about 5 seconds, then goes dark
You can't tell if you got a notification or not until you either tap the display or pick the phone up(if you have those settings configured)
This really should have been an always on display, and probably still could be if oneplus just changes when it's active
The battery lasts a long time, more than a day for me
I'd gladly trade a few % of that to have the always on display

Several unfortunate problems sink this flagship
Some great potential here, but for a $1,000 flagship phone it is a huge disappointment
Others have summarized the good points so I am going to focus on the bad:1
Despite false advertising, this phone is not dual SIM in the USA at least
An update has been promised since April next update but every update it is the same, no dual SIM
The curved edge is critical to control this phone - scrolling, back and forward, etc
Very cool and it works great except that it is impossible to hold the phone securely without activating the edge controls
This means you have to hold the phone in the palm of your hand without touching the sides - not an easy trick and it makes it easy to drop the phone
Because of the edge control issue, cases are poorly made for this phone
I have tried three including the official OnePlus case, and all have the same issue - the edge protector ridge interferes with the swiping needed for edge control functions
We have a documented issue where messages SMS that messages that are actually sent show up as unsent
This problem reappears from time to time and OnePlus tech supports only answer is to totally reset the phone from firmware boot ROM (losing all apps and app data)
I just ignore the  message not sent errors now but that is unacceptable in a flagship
I got a lot more life on my Moto z4
Maybe the issue is the impressive 120hz display which looks amazing
But battery life is just too short

This is my first Oneplus phone, I opted for the non-pro version because of the slightly smaller screen, and the fact that the hardware specs I care about were identical on both (90hz is more than enough for me, and going from 60hz to 90hz is much more important than 90hz to 120hz)
The main con for me is that there's no external storage options, which is the one thing I miss the most from the S10e I replaced this with
My other main issue has to do with the OS
My other gripes are more with the industry as a whole right now which this phone copied, so they are problems with pretty much any good phone right now
5 inch screen anyway, so it's not like things even look better on it

I like the phone enough that I'll definitely consider Oneplus phones in another couple of years when I might upgrade again though (I like it overall better than Samsung that I have my own gripes with), I just hope OP offers a version with a smaller, flat screen, and adds external storage options, and it would be almost a completely perfect phone

Comparison between. One Plus Pro 7 5G and 8 Pro vs Samsung Galaxy S20 Ultra
I did not buy this on Amazon but I owned the Galaxy 3, 5, 7, Galaxy Note 8, Galaxy 10, One+ 7 Pro 5G, then the Galaxy s20 Ultra, and now the One+ 8 Pro
Galaxy S20 Ultra on 5GIt has a hard time jumping between 4G to 5G and drops calls a lot of the time
Surfing the internet:Galaxy S20 Ultra: great until you get to a weaker signal area, where it switches between 5G and 4G, then it can leave you hanging especially with games
One Plus 7 Pro 5G graphics are a little less intense
Samsung Galaxy Ultra S20:The sound is loud, but its not an experience
Charge Times:The 7 Pro 5G and 8pro both charge rapidly with their warp chargers, problem is you have to buy extra warp car chargers for the cars, that gets pricy
0 they charge at the same rate the Galaxy S20 Ultra does, so due to price of equipment, I'd say Samsung Galaxy S20 Ultra is about even
00 on a warp car charger (knockoffs burn out )The stock Keyboard: One+ 7 pro 5G and 8 Pro is attrocious for big fingers, you'll have to download a different one
Samsung Galaxy S20 Ultra works perfectly
Finger Printing and Face recognition:The One Plus on both phones, does a better job at finger prints
The samsung galaxy actually worked with my face mask on, so win there
Picture Taking:Long distance Photos;Samsung Galaxy Ultra S20 wins
Regular Photographs: One Plus is the clear winner
Overall I highly recommend going with the One Plus 8 Pro

Main takeaways to buy this phone:- if you want newest specs of OnePlus but don't want to shell out extra 100-200 dollars for top of the line camera, wireless charging, or 120hz display-interstellar glow-oxygen OS-ultra fast interfaceHaving switched from an iPhone 6s plus, this was obviously a tremendous upgrade
Almost got the regular 7 pro from last year but as I don't buy a new phone often I decided to get the newest they had to offer
it's the other subtleties. Plus flagship quality
This review is for the 8GB RAM, 128GB storage, teal blue, unlocked US version (not service provider specific, not custom T-Mobile or Verizon)
I am very satisfied with how well my 1+8 performs in all those aspects
With expensive aesthetic phones& their goofy fragile glass shells, everyone has to put a protective case of some kind on them
So how much does their naked appearance & feel really matter?With a case, I cannot tell if phone has a plastic or glass shell, and the feel of it's shape is altered
So I don't care about shell material & little about shape;a plastic shell would be just fine
The curved edge displays are a nuisance;it's too easy to make unintended screen touches, though a case helps mitigate that problem
I don't want a HUGE phone
Slippery glass & huge size make it more likely I will drop my expensive fragile phone
Bright HDR with high resolution is desirable
Before ordering, the negative reviews scared me
What I've assimilated from many sources suggests the comments here are more negative than the real average of comments from all owners
I notice & appreciate the quality vibration mechanism; it's much nicer than any I've felt before
It's cool to regularly feel a little knock when some step happens
And it's cool to be able to set various vibration patterns for various system events, similar to setting distinct ringtones
While this phone's 90hz display refresh is VERY nice, I don't find 90 or 120hz refresh rates to be nearly as important as reviewers do
I'm not a phone gamer
My phone is primarily for communicating
A little photo editing with Snapseed works perfectly
But no games
I find this phone perfect for those things
I am happy with picture quality, not perturbed like some reviews about some small compromise design trade-offs OnePlus made with the cameras
I didn't pay $900 for this
If I want perfect photos I grab my Olympus TG-2 for great pictures, esp
And this phone has excellent video performance
265 encoding as an option is great;it reduces file size
The 1+8's RAM & Snapdragon 865 perform noticeably fast & make it VERY responsive
Impressive how this hardware can compensate for the poor software performance
I REALLY like the lack of bloatware, how close Oxygen OS 11 is to standard Android 11, and 1+ policy for OS upgrades & security patches
I dislike the way Samsung and Verizon customize Android and add their own apps (bloatware) to their phones and devices
Corded charging is so wonderfully FAST & convenient that I disagree with the fuss reviewers make re: lack of wireless charging
Its physical switch for silencing the phone like an iPhone, while not important, is handy
Plus it has a built in equalizer that works for everthing
On other phones I have never been able to get an equalizer app to work with all the audio apps
So I usually could not compensate for different frequency capabilities on various listening devices
I can now!Stereo audio in general on this phone is impressive
The speakers are on each end of the phone, yeilding better stereo separation
Mine excels at WiFi 6 (with it's multiple antenas) and WPA3 security
I use the T-mobile network, and so far it's the only carrier in our area providing 5G
I get superior 4G LTE performance and some 5G connections
When I get 5G it is FAST
That's a phone service thing, not the phone
This phone supports most of the frequency bands the providers use, more bands than many other phones, like phones sold by Verizon or T-Mobile
I sometimes use it as a hotspot that is faster than my home cable Internet service (I'm cheap, it's limited to about 32mbps)
1 LE works great with my BT 5 devices
Call audio and video quality are excellent, according to people I've spoken & done video calls with

I’m probably not the best person to review an Android phone as I prefer Apple, but that said, this phone was surprising
Appearance & Handling: The phone itself is very shiny and attracts a lot of fingerprints though
Battery & Charging: The battery lasts a good long while because of it and there are also a lot of customization/setting options to extend the battery life a little more
Customization Settings: This phone has a lot of options built in for a more personal touch as most Android phones do
Gorgeous Display and T-Mobile 5G Works Well
As of August 2020, this is one of the least expensive 5G phones out there, and the 5G connection works reasonably well on T-Mobile

Good Phone
Bought it during Prime Day
I didn't have 5G on my old phone
I was told by Tmobile that I needed a 5G sim card
I got the 5G sim and so far no issues
Fast, Fast, and Takes Great Photos
I normally stick to the Nexus/Pixel phones, apart from special use cases
This phone has changed my mind, with an overall snappier experience and better screen
If 4G could already stream 4K video, is there really any point?I think the answer is sort of
To my surprise, the phone immediately connected to a 5G tower after setting up my SIM card
What I noticed is that web pages and apps that rely on network speed updated super fast when I clicked on something
The low latency is really the difference here
It makes everything feel a little more seamless, even compared to my home computer
With that said, I can't do anything with my phone that I couldn't before
A movie won't look any better, for instance
There is no reason to spend a lot on 5G just yet, even if it is nice to have
The star is the 90 Hz refresh rate, which makes scrolling through web pages and animations look silky smooth
It is hard to go back once you adapt to it
Black levels are also nice and ghosting, while present, is minimal
FINGERPRINT READERIt seems that some companies are jumping on the in-screen fingerprint reader while others are holding out
I definitely prefer a quick fingerprint over face scanning
The tech here is really cool and looks futuristic, lighting up the finger that is being scanned
It works, but is a bit more sensitive to position than the standard scanners
In other words, you can't just get your finger close like my last phone
I also miss having the thumb scanner on the back of the phone, where my finger naturally lies as I pick it up
That made it more instant
I am neutral overall on this
Cool technology, but perhaps the old way works better
Popping between apps feels almost instant
It helps that the OS has very little weighing it down, with mostly a stock experience
There are a few apps that refuse to be removed without rooting, unfortunately, but those are primarily maintenance and Google stuff
This is really a wonderful phone to use
There is fast charging, which means I can forget to charge it and still get it charged most of the way while getting ready
Speaking of charge, it can easily last a day and usually a little longer with normal usage
The battery seems to drain faster when using the 90 Hz mode, but it is worth it and the battery life is still good
Even compared to iPhone, there is just nothing that can beat them
This phone is actually a good competitor, with the best photo quality I have seen outside of a Pixel
The 48 MP mode is interesting
It has no zoom function, being a static widescreen camera
It has its uses for sure
The standard camera, including for video, has great focus and color reproduction
If you are worried about sacrificing camera quality, don't be
Even without that, it is fast, has good battery life, and a great camera
A lot nicer then I was expecting! Love the space and the camera!
I've updated my review to just make it simpler sounding

----I've had this phone about 2 weeks now, I personally had an old budget Samsung Orbit phone (a $100 range tracfone), I was curious in seeing how such an expensive phone compared to my phone I already owned
I saw some reviews saying the dual sim doesn't work, not a feature I need but the packaging of the phone states it's a feature that will be Incorporated in the future
-The quality of the photos you take with this phone are stunning way more detailed then any phone I've ever had before

the space this phone has is perfect I feel like I'll never run out of space again, I always hated having to remove apps to make room for more and having trouble picking what to delete!-Phone looks great, speaker records audio well and the phone works pretty fast
-Battery life + charging is better then any phone I've had before (I'm coming from budget phones though)

-The finger print sensor works well and seems to be able to handle minor falls pretty well!-Some preinstalled apps on this aren't the best but you can download better alternatives, I do miss the Galaxy Themes app that I don't see a good alternative for on OnePlus8

-I love that it comes with a screen protector already preinstalled on the front, feel like all phones should come with one preinstalled!Not having experience with other high end phones, I feel like I can understand why phones like these do cost more

I didn't know how to feel about having no removable battery at first, but with how long it keeps a charge and with how fast this phone charges, it's really not an issue!An issue I had that I have gotten over that probably isn't an issue to others, is I do like a physical button on the front of my phone, it's the way I prefer to turn on my phone, so I disliked that I personally didn't see a way to open the OnePlus8 from the front unless you enabled the finger print scanner, I have gotten use tothe lack of one
--I ended up having an issue with the mic not working at one point, contact OnePlus's customer service they were very nice and ended up finding out dust had just got stuck in the bottom mic
OnePlus 8 Interstellar
First let me start by saying that I received this phone in the Interstellar Glow coloration and it looks absolutely amazing! Coming in with a 6
55 screen, it also features an adaptive display, motion graphics smoothing and Vibrant Color Effect Pro

Inside the phone, it features 8GB of RAM which helps load times be quicker, and 256GB internal storage which gives plenty of space to save your pictures, games and anything else you want without having to worry as much about the amounts you have
Speaking of pictures, this phone comes with a set of cameras that are breathtaking

Other than that, this phone is absolutely amazing and well worth it's price! OnePlus was a brand I had never heard of before, but they are a brand that I would recommend to anyone looking for a new phone! Absolutely amazing quality!

So what about this phone, in a little more detail? This isn't the place for a thorough technical dive into each of the following things, so read up them from professional reviewers if you want specifics
Let's get the worst one out of the way first: The screen is terrible
So this is absolutely not a screen you should expect to get a great color experience from
It features a chipset that, at the time it was made (spring 2020), was reasonably high-end but not top of the line
It features a very minimally-altered Android experience
It also has one of the better update and security policies for Android phones
Battery life is great: two to three days of minimal use/standby, a full day even at moderate/heavy use
It's got NFC! Most budget Android phones seem to discard NFC, but this one has it
No headphone jack or microSDHC storage expansion support
The metal case looks nice but it is very, very slick and slippery
Expanded integration and exclusive extra features with other OnePlus accessories, if you are a wider OnePlus customer
All-in-all then, it's fine

-Oxygen OS is by far one of my favorites of the phone, it's lightweight and not bogged down by anything

-Games run very smooth!-Battery life is pretty amazing, 4500mah last a LONG timeCons-Some people may be turned off that by default Netflix comes installed on the phone(Though the HDR on it is AMAZING LOOKING)-Transitioning from an Apple or Samsung may leave some software features to desire, possibly UI issues you do not like

-That being said if you want alexa, it's in the app store, if not you're set!Conclusion-This phone was controversial in a that it was a flagship, from a company that has historically against flagships

I compared to a 8t+ (my sons) and I did notice a difference in battery life and speed from the DDR5 vs
Other than that both phones are about identical in RAM/ROM, etc
I keep a charge stand on my bedside table and desk

It is water resistant rated vs
Easily 500+mbs on T-Mobile all over town

Especially if you get it used or renewed and save big bucks
Highly recommend

Reason I needed this setup:I have been looking for a device to decouple myself from Google Voice, OEM/google bloatware and ridiculous cell phone contracts/plan pricing for 5 years, I have 2 numbers I need to keep
work and business
I am not going to carry two phones or pay for two 40-90$/mo plans

So I waited
Now was the time!Got the phone yesterday

I upgraded to the OnePlus 8 from a Pixel 2XL, and I have thoroughly enjoyed this phone so far! I was a little hesitant buying this phone (with some complaining about the camera, and so many other phones releasing this fall), but this phone has surpassed my expectations! I wasn't interested in the OnePlus 8 Pro because of the larger size/weight and more expensive price tag
The screen is big and beautiful! The hole punch camera doesn't bother me at all, and I forget it is there most of the time
Speaking of buttery smooth, this phone will handle anything you throw at it! The combination of the beefy specs (emphasis on the 8gb/12 gb of RAM) and OxygenOS make for an amazing experience
The battery life has been fantastic
The on-screen fingerprint reader is very fast and I rarely have issues unlocking the phone
The stereo speakers are pretty great, and I have no issues with the sound quality
The build quality is very premium and feels like a $1000 phone
In my opinion, the camera is not nearly as bad as some people are saying

It has a minor issue that oneplus could improve upon
I miss having an always on display
The oneplus 8 has kind of a half-azzed version of that
The display will light up for notifications, but only the instant you get them, then the screen returns to darkness
That is nearly useless since I'm not staring at my phone constantly
There's also no indicator light to let you know you've gotten notifications
So basically when you get a notification of any kind, the phone's half on display flashes for about 5 seconds, then goes dark
You can't tell if you got a notification or not until you either tap the display or pick the phone up(if you have those settings configured)
This really should have been an always on display, and probably still could be if oneplus just changes when it's active
The battery lasts a long time, more than a day for me
I'd gladly trade a few % of that to have the always on display

Several unfortunate problems sink this flagship
Some great potential here, but for a $1,000 flagship phone it is a huge disappointment
Others have summarized the good points so I am going to focus on the bad:1
Despite false advertising, this phone is not dual SIM in the USA at least
An update has been promised since April next update but every update it is the same, no dual SIM
The curved edge is critical to control this phone - scrolling, back and forward, etc
Very cool and it works great except that it is impossible to hold the phone securely without activating the edge controls
This means you have to hold the phone in the palm of your hand without touching the sides - not an easy trick and it makes it easy to drop the phone
Because of the edge control issue, cases are poorly made for this phone
I have tried three including the official OnePlus case, and all have the same issue - the edge protector ridge interferes with the swiping needed for edge control functions
We have a documented issue where messages SMS that messages that are actually sent show up as unsent
This problem reappears from time to time and OnePlus tech supports only answer is to totally reset the phone from firmware boot ROM (losing all apps and app data)
I just ignore the  message not sent errors now but that is unacceptable in a flagship
I got a lot more life on my Moto z4
Maybe the issue is the impressive 120hz display which looks amazing
But battery life is just too short

This is my first Oneplus phone, I opted for the non-pro version because of the slightly smaller screen, and the fact that the hardware specs I care about were identical on both (90hz is more than enough for me, and going from 60hz to 90hz is much more important than 90hz to 120hz)
The main con for me is that there's no external storage options, which is the one thing I miss the most from the S10e I replaced this with
My other main issue has to do with the OS
My other gripes are more with the industry as a whole right now which this phone copied, so they are problems with pretty much any good phone right now
5 inch screen anyway, so it's not like things even look better on it

I like the phone enough that I'll definitely consider Oneplus phones in another couple of years when I might upgrade again though (I like it overall better than Samsung that I have my own gripes with), I just hope OP offers a version with a smaller, flat screen, and adds external storage options, and it would be almost a completely perfect phone

Comparison between. One Plus Pro 7 5G and 8 Pro vs Samsung Galaxy S20 Ultra
I did not buy this on Amazon but I owned the Galaxy 3, 5, 7, Galaxy Note 8, Galaxy 10, One+ 7 Pro 5G, then the Galaxy s20 Ultra, and now the One+ 8 Pro
Galaxy S20 Ultra on 5GIt has a hard time jumping between 4G to 5G and drops calls a lot of the time
Surfing the internet:Galaxy S20 Ultra: great until you get to a weaker signal area, where it switches between 5G and 4G, then it can leave you hanging especially with games
One Plus 7 Pro 5G graphics are a little less intense
Samsung Galaxy Ultra S20:The sound is loud, but its not an experience
Charge Times:The 7 Pro 5G and 8pro both charge rapidly with their warp chargers, problem is you have to buy extra warp car chargers for the cars, that gets pricy
0 they charge at the same rate the Galaxy S20 Ultra does, so due to price of equipment, I'd say Samsung Galaxy S20 Ultra is about even
00 on a warp car charger (knockoffs burn out )The stock Keyboard: One+ 7 pro 5G and 8 Pro is attrocious for big fingers, you'll have to download a different one
Samsung Galaxy S20 Ultra works perfectly
Finger Printing and Face recognition:The One Plus on both phones, does a better job at finger prints
The samsung galaxy actually worked with my face mask on, so win there
Picture Taking:Long distance Photos;Samsung Galaxy Ultra S20 wins
Regular Photographs: One Plus is the clear winner
Overall I highly recommend going with the One Plus 8 Pro

Main takeaways to buy this phone:- if you want newest specs of OnePlus but don't want to shell out extra 100-200 dollars for top of the line camera, wireless charging, or 120hz display-interstellar glow-oxygen OS-ultra fast interfaceHaving switched from an iPhone 6s plus, this was obviously a tremendous upgrade
Almost got the regular 7 pro from last year but as I don't buy a new phone often I decided to get the newest they had to offer
it's the other subtleties. Plus flagship quality
This review is for the 8GB RAM, 128GB storage, teal blue, unlocked US version (not service provider specific, not custom T-Mobile or Verizon)
I am very satisfied with how well my 1+8 performs in all those aspects
With expensive aesthetic phones& their goofy fragile glass shells, everyone has to put a protective case of some kind on them
So how much does their naked appearance & feel really matter?With a case, I cannot tell if phone has a plastic or glass shell, and the feel of it's shape is altered
So I don't care about shell material & little about shape;a plastic shell would be just fine
The curved edge displays are a nuisance;it's too easy to make unintended screen touches, though a case helps mitigate that problem
I don't want a HUGE phone
Slippery glass & huge size make it more likely I will drop my expensive fragile phone
Bright HDR with high resolution is desirable
Before ordering, the negative reviews scared me
What I've assimilated from many sources suggests the comments here are more negative than the real average of comments from all owners
I notice & appreciate the quality vibration mechanism; it's much nicer than any I've felt before
It's cool to regularly feel a little knock when some step happens
And it's cool to be able to set various vibration patterns for various system events, similar to setting distinct ringtones
While this phone's 90hz display refresh is VERY nice, I don't find 90 or 120hz refresh rates to be nearly as important as reviewers do
I'm not a phone gamer
My phone is primarily for communicating
A little photo editing with Snapseed works perfectly
But no games
I find this phone perfect for those things
I am happy with picture quality, not perturbed like some reviews about some small compromise design trade-offs OnePlus made with the cameras
I didn't pay $900 for this
If I want perfect photos I grab my Olympus TG-2 for great pictures, esp
And this phone has excellent video performance
265 encoding as an option is great;it reduces file size
The 1+8's RAM & Snapdragon 865 perform noticeably fast & make it VERY responsive
Impressive how this hardware can compensate for the poor software performance
I REALLY like the lack of bloatware, how close Oxygen OS 11 is to standard Android 11, and 1+ policy for OS upgrades & security patches
I dislike the way Samsung and Verizon customize Android and add their own apps (bloatware) to their phones and devices
Corded charging is so wonderfully FAST & convenient that I disagree with the fuss reviewers make re: lack of wireless charging
Its physical switch for silencing the phone like an iPhone, while not important, is handy
Plus it has a built in equalizer that works for everthing
On other phones I have never been able to get an equalizer app to work with all the audio apps
So I usually could not compensate for different frequency capabilities on various listening devices
I can now!Stereo audio in general on this phone is impressive
The speakers are on each end of the phone, yeilding better stereo separation
Mine excels at WiFi 6 (with it's multiple antenas) and WPA3 security
I use the T-mobile network, and so far it's the only carrier in our area providing 5G
I get superior 4G LTE performance and some 5G connections
When I get 5G it is FAST
That's a phone service thing, not the phone
This phone supports most of the frequency bands the providers use, more bands than many other phones, like phones sold by Verizon or T-Mobile
I sometimes use it as a hotspot that is faster than my home cable Internet service (I'm cheap, it's limited to about 32mbps)
1 LE works great with my BT 5 devices
Call audio and video quality are excellent, according to people I've spoken & done video calls with

I’m probably not the best person to review an Android phone as I prefer Apple, but that said, this phone was surprising
Appearance & Handling: The phone itself is very shiny and attracts a lot of fingerprints though
Battery & Charging: The battery lasts a good long while because of it and there are also a lot of customization/setting options to extend the battery life a little more
Customization Settings: This phone has a lot of options built in for a more personal touch as most Android phones do
Gorgeous Display and T-Mobile 5G Works Well
As of August 2020, this is one of the least expensive 5G phones out there, and the 5G connection works reasonably well on T-Mobile
The 2 bad things about this phone are that it is very slippery and has a tendency to fall from your hands
Good Phone
Bought it during Prime Day
I didn't have 5G on my old phone
I was told by Tmobile that I needed a 5G sim card
I got the 5G sim and so far no issues
Fast, Fast, and Takes Great Photos
I normally stick to the Nexus/Pixel phones, apart from special use cases
This phone has changed my mind, with an overall snappier experience and better screen
If 4G could already stream 4K video, is there really any point?I think the answer is sort of
To my surprise, the phone immediately connected to a 5G tower after setting up my SIM card
What I noticed is that web pages and apps that rely on network speed updated super fast when I clicked on something
The low latency is really the difference here
It makes everything feel a little more seamless, even compared to my home computer
With that said, I can't do anything with my phone that I couldn't before
A movie won't look any better, for instance
There is no reason to spend a lot on 5G just yet, even if it is nice to have
The star is the 90 Hz refresh rate, which makes scrolling through web pages and animations look silky smooth
It is hard to go back once you adapt to it
Black levels are also nice and ghosting, while present, is minimal
FINGERPRINT READERIt seems that some companies are jumping on the in-screen fingerprint reader while others are holding out
I definitely prefer a quick fingerprint over face scanning
The tech here is really cool and looks futuristic, lighting up the finger that is being scanned
It works, but is a bit more sensitive to position than the standard scanners
In other words, you can't just get your finger close like my last phone
I also miss having the thumb scanner on the back of the phone, where my finger naturally lies as I pick it up
That made it more instant
I am neutral overall on this
Cool technology, but perhaps the old way works better
Popping between apps feels almost instant
It helps that the OS has very little weighing it down, with mostly a stock experience
There are a few apps that refuse to be removed without rooting, unfortunately, but those are primarily maintenance and Google stuff
This is really a wonderful phone to use
There is fast charging, which means I can forget to charge it and still get it charged most of the way while getting ready
Speaking of charge, it can easily last a day and usually a little longer with normal usage
The battery seems to drain faster when using the 90 Hz mode, but it is worth it and the battery life is still good
Even compared to iPhone, there is just nothing that can beat them
This phone is actually a good competitor, with the best photo quality I have seen outside of a Pixel
The 48 MP mode is interesting
It has no zoom function, being a static widescreen camera
It has its uses for sure
The standard camera, including for video, has great focus and color reproduction
If you are worried about sacrificing camera quality, don't be
Even without that, it is fast, has good battery life, and a great camera
A lot nicer then I was expecting! Love the space and the camera!
I've updated my review to just make it simpler sounding

----I've had this phone about 2 weeks now, I personally had an old budget Samsung Orbit phone (a $100 range tracfone), I was curious in seeing how such an expensive phone compared to my phone I already owned
I saw some reviews saying the dual sim doesn't work, not a feature I need but the packaging of the phone states it's a feature that will be Incorporated in the future
-The quality of the photos you take with this phone are stunning way more detailed then any phone I've ever had before

the space this phone has is perfect I feel like I'll never run out of space again, I always hated having to remove apps to make room for more and having trouble picking what to delete!-Phone looks great, speaker records audio well and the phone works pretty fast
-Battery life + charging is better then any phone I've had before (I'm coming from budget phones though)

-The finger print sensor works well and seems to be able to handle minor falls pretty well!-Some preinstalled apps on this aren't the best but you can download better alternatives, I do miss the Galaxy Themes app that I don't see a good alternative for on OnePlus8

-I love that it comes with a screen protector already preinstalled on the front, feel like all phones should come with one preinstalled!Not having experience with other high end phones, I feel like I can understand why phones like these do cost more

I didn't know how to feel about having no removable battery at first, but with how long it keeps a charge and with how fast this phone charges, it's really not an issue!An issue I had that I have gotten over that probably isn't an issue to others, is I do like a physical button on the front of my phone, it's the way I prefer to turn on my phone, so I disliked that I personally didn't see a way to open the OnePlus8 from the front unless you enabled the finger print scanner, I have gotten use tothe lack of one
--I ended up having an issue with the mic not working at one point, contact OnePlus's customer service they were very nice and ended up finding out dust had just got stuck in the bottom mic
OnePlus 8 Interstellar
First let me start by saying that I received this phone in the Interstellar Glow coloration and it looks absolutely amazing! Coming in with a 6
55 screen, it also features an adaptive display, motion graphics smoothing and Vibrant Color Effect Pro

Speaking of pictures, this phone comes with a set of cameras that are breathtaking

Other than that, this phone is absolutely amazing and well worth it's price! OnePlus was a brand I had never heard of before, but they are a brand that I would recommend to anyone looking for a new phone! Absolutely amazing quality!

Purchased my OP8 PRO 8n April 2020 when it first came out
Initially I was quite pleased with the phone
In screen fingerprint reader is just ok, and often takes a couple of tries to get in (miss the Pixel rear reader)
Performance has been consistently good
Minor bugs keep popping up here and there (among others there was the PIP erratic behavior at one point, now loss of navigation buttons and stuck rotation when leaving a full screen landscaped app)
Coming from a Pixel I was used to monthly updates and in the beginning the OP8 Pro updates were quite often
Now that they have settled in to a ho hum every other month, I find myself disappointed that it takes 2 months to receive the latest security updates (still running Nov 2020 patch as I write this)
Really miss the anti-spam features of the Google Phone app, which are missing from the oneplus dialer app

In the end, now that Google has restored the fingerprint reader to the Pixel line and assuming they return to putting a top of the line SOC in the Pixels with a decent battery, I will probably switch back in another year

A perfectly reasonable budget Android phone, if it is discounted. NOT a flagship though.
Depending on the price, this is either a very respectable and competitive budget Android phone or an absolute rip-off that should be avoided at all costs
It is a spring-of-2020 phone that was positioned as a not-quite-flagship and, at the time, vastly overpriced for what it was
As of this writing the Pixel 5a is a much closer competitor, but for $100 more

So what about this phone, in a little more detail? This isn't the place for a thorough technical dive into each of the following things, so read up them from professional reviewers if you want specifics
Let's get the worst one out of the way first: The screen is terrible
So this is absolutely not a screen you should expect to get a great color experience from
It features a chipset that, at the time it was made (spring 2020), was reasonably high-end but not top of the line
It features a very minimally-altered Android experience
It also has one of the better update and security policies for Android phones
Battery life is great: two to three days of minimal use/standby, a full day even at moderate/heavy use
It's got NFC! Most budget Android phones seem to discard NFC, but this one has it
No headphone jack or microSDHC storage expansion support
The metal case looks nice but it is very, very slick and slippery
Expanded integration and exclusive extra features with other OnePlus accessories, if you are a wider OnePlus customer
All-in-all then, it's fine

This product looks and feels like 1990s “state of the art” cellphone technology
All entries are essentially accomplished “pick & pray” using the smallish keys
For example, to enter letter “S” you have to keep depressing the #7 key repeatedly
The only literature enclosed was a small leaflet that demonstrates how to insert the battery (which ships packed outside the phone)
No instruction manual included
I found a bit of information online, but hardly enough
My advice if needing a cheap phone for a foreign trip or other shorter period would be to buy a used or refurbished Apple, Samsung or other top-branded phone
Even a 10-year old Apple iPhone would be miles ahead of this product for ease of use, functionalityand overall design

Snappiest budget Android smartphone
I bought this smartphone for an upcoming family trip outside the country
I was looking for a budget phone with a large enough screen for entertainment, mid range performance, and a price without breaking the bank
Got this phone as recommended by a family friend
So far, I am impressed
Inside the box is the smartphone, a transparent case, usb c cable, charger, and user guide
The USB C charger is such a joy, as I don’t have to carry extra chargers since most of my other devices are using USB C
The chassis of this smartphone feels very premium comparable to $1000 phones, however, the back of the phone is a fingerprint magnet
But it shouldn’t matter since I am using the case anyways
The initial setup is very quick, I was able to login and make phone calls in just a couple of minutes
The Android 12 system is pretty much vanilla or stock, other than having pre-installed TCL apps
The 64GB storage is good enough for essential apps, but I did add a 256GB micro sd card just in case I need to take videos and photos
The camera is very clear and sharp in my opinion, but it does lack a little dynamic range
The image colors are comparable to Fujifilm cameras‘ classic chrome film simulation
The display is not the greatest, but nice enough for entertainment in a long plane ride
I have to set up the display in “vivid” mode just to get nicer colors
The large wide screen makes watching movies more immersive
The speakers are surprisingly loud, watching youtube videos without earphones are very much enjoyable
I rarely make phone calls, but the call quality is very good
I can clearly hear the person I’m talking to and vice versa
One of the features that I really like is the combination of the fingerprint sensor and face unlock
I know these features are very common now, but the fact that this phone is very snappy using face unlock is very impressive
The phone came with a pre-installed “Game Zone” app that contains lots of casual games
The phone performs exceptionally well with casual games, perfect for passing time
The battery life is what I have expected at 5000mAh, it can last me up to 2 days of casual use
The premium quality and performance are way above its price level
Highly recommended for casual users

Consumer Cellular APN
Great phone
But if you have consumer Cellular, you will need their tech support if you don't have mobile data, and you may have to wait on hold for an hour
They need to help you change the APN
Go to settings/sim card and cellular network/ at the very top, click cellular network again, access point names/ then the + sign to add a new APN
They will need your sim card number, which is the second one on the sim card
I hope that helps you
The incorrect APN makes it so that you cannot receive pictures or stickers or gifs in text among other things
I would also like to address some of the negative reviews that I see for this phone

WiFi upgrade
I bought this phone (for about $10 more) primarily to continue using my old iPad with the University of Arizona's new WiFi server
Those who want if for a cell phone may have different opinions
It took a while to figure out how to a) connect to UAWIFi and b) how to tether the phone to my iPad via Bluetooth
Here's the critical piece of information: after pairing the devices in Bluetooth, go to Settings>Network & Internet>Tethering & mobile hotspot and turn on Bluetooth tethering
It works beautifully; I'm using it right now
Best $30 upgrade I've ever purchased
Low quality display and small battery
This is the cheapest way to get something resembling a current real phone, so I'm giving it some points for that
But everything about it is sub-par
The display has no viewing angle
The resolution is a bit weak
Automatic brightness is more erratic than average, but you can fix that with any of multiple free brightness control apps
The front of the phone is some lower-end material and doesn't have a smooth feel when swiping

The navigation buttons don't have proper icons, and while I prefer a dedicated nav area (not part of the display, so apps can't hide it on you) it's weird that the recent apps and back buttons are both just a dot
The battery is not especially big

So what is it still good for? If you need nothing but phone calls and occasionally important apps like for banking, or when some company wants you to use their app for access to various things, or if you don't have access to a desktop for whatever purpose, you do get a working smartphone for cheap
