In the Box:-The phone came brand new in the Motorola box with the chord, charger, pin to extract the SIM car/SD card holder, and clear phone case-Cons: directions were in Spanish (but images were pretty universal and most things were self-explanatory), free case is slippery and doesn't seem like it will provide much protectionPhone Itself:This is an excellent budget phone! So far

-Camera functions well (does not compare to the Pixel 4 or iPhone 11, but really great for the price)-Battery is very good (2 full days of use between charges)-Very quick processing for everyday use-TONS of built-in storage and room for expandable memory-Excellent speaker quality- Dolby settings is a great added bonus-Huge display with very little taken away for the camera in notched display-Finger print sensor on the back is great, with option to have PIN/swipe to unlock if phone is face-up on a table or something

My last three out of four Motorola Gs Failed in one way or another (2 had bad cameras, 1 The flash / light quit working, My last G7 Battery swelled, splitting the phone in half!)I have purchase Motorola products since the 60s

At one time back in the 60s every fire Department, Police Department in this country used Motorola communication devices, radios and walkies talkies for their quality and dependability and would never think about any other Manufacturer
What has happened to this one time world class company?This phone, I recommend you don't use the turbocharger and don't leave it plugged in all the time

Best radio I have used on a phone so far. and a superb phone for that price.
I live in a hilly country where we have known bad spots for phone reception and I deliberately tested ib these areas
This phone went through the two worst areas and the signal did not drop on my conversation - a friend and I were betting on the call cutting away
I did the same test with other phones - I am a ham operator so I play with devices like that
The other features on the phone are excellent
The touch screen responds well, the Bluetooth radio connects easily and has good range, and the camera system is excellent
I choose phones mainly based on camera quality, radio strength on transmit and receive, and battery life
This unit does well on all three in my view
I have s single challenge with the headphone jack feelin slightly loose so I am not able to use a plugged in headphone unless I wriggle it and hold - meaning I will have to use only Bluetooth
And I was not happy that a headphone did not come in the box

I would have been happy to pay a few extra dollars to have a headphone to use out of the box, especially when Amazon customer service will inevitably ask whether I am using a compatible set with the phone
Had the headphone jack not been an issue this phone would be getting five stars, hands down
I am hoping the seller sees this and can make adjustments going forward

Response is excellent, graphics crisp, and the action camera is really impressive
My daughter bought the G7 Power last year, and her only gripe is that the camera was very average
She's a bit jealous of this one
These Motos are somewhat heavier than their much more expensive relatives because they have a large battery

Although not quite as big as the G7 Power's (5000 mAH) battery, this phone's 4000 mAH battery was fully charged 43 hours ago, and has seen a ton of use with the addition of apps, configuration and other messing around
The battery still shows 52% remaining
It was a bit finicky setting up with ATT
I'm a long-time customer with several lines, and they don't charge me to swap sims at the retail store

I purchased this phone to replace a Motorola G7+ with a smashed screen
The phone was ordered on a Sunday and was supposed to be delivered on Wednesday
As delivered it came with a silicon cover
Popping the Mint SIM and micro SD card from the G7 to the G8+ was easy using the included pin
Software transfer from a backup of the G7 was basically seamless
Although some of the apps I used needed updates
The Motorola G8+ was not sold in the USA
This means that the software updates came with Spanish language descriptions (the updates themselves are not languagedependent)
The only real annoyance to me was that when I bought the phone it didn't support wifi calling
This was a serious problem for me because I depend on wifi calling at my second home as there is no cell coverage
I resigned myself to either returning itor waiting til I needed to replace it
So I am up at my second home, and I get a phone call on my G*+

SPOILER ALERT! Amazon Prime Phone is Amazing
ONE WEEK IN AS OF 6/15/17I received this phone approximately one week ago
WHY A PRIME PHONEI've been with Sprint for about 16 years and although I have loyalty to them, they have zero loyalty to me
Please also note that my last 3-4 phones were Samsung phones which I loved dearly so my comparison is everything from the Galaxy S3 forward

SPOILER ALERT - AMAZONcame through again, big time by offering this phone to prime members!ONE THING I'D DO DIFFERENTLY - MICRO SD CARD DECISIONSo you don't have to suffer through my Moto G 5 dissertation, the one thing that irritates me - and I did it somewhat on my own, is that I selected a 128 gb micro sd card that came up as an option while I was buying the phone
FIRST IMPRESSIONSI received the phone in two days being a prime member
To fully get the phone set up, I had to get to a Sprint store to get a sim card
WHAT I HAVE COME TO LOVEAlmost Stock Android - I didn't realize how much tweaking if Android had been done on my Note 4 and previous phones
THE FINGERPRINT SCANNER/MAGIC BUTTON IN THE MIDDLEI've used fingerprint technology since the early days
After a couple of days, I received a message asking if I wanted to get rid of the navigation buttons at the bottom of the page
VOLUME BUTTON AND ON/OFF LOCATIONI know this is very myopic but having the volume button and the on/off button on the right side of the phone is really handy
MICRO SD CARDHopefully, you read this up front but buy a micro sd card that meets the specs
THE SMARTPHONE THAT IS SMARTSo on the plane, I plugged in my headset and my phone spoke to me
SCREEN RESOLUTIONHonestly, I could care less if my phone screen is 4k
SCREEN SPACEOne thing I find interesting is that I can put much more on a page of the Moto G5 screen than I could on my Note 4
GORILLA GLASSThe Moto G5 Plus comes with gorilla glass, saving me from having to purchase any sort of shield - yes, I am that guy who normally gets a glass shield on his phone
AMAZON ADSOh, and I'm frugal so I chose to have the Amazon ads show up
and although I've been tempted, I haven't pulled the trigger on a purchase yet
BATTERY LIFEBattery life in this first week is more than acceptable
This has to be one of the best bargain smartphones on the market
This has to be one of the best bargain smartphones on the market
I purchased for just over 200 bucks with the built in adware on the idle screen which does not seem to be any big deal with me
It is every bit as good as my company provided Samsung Galaxy 7
The screen is as good as I’ve seen and the audio is plenty loud despite some reports of it being low
Perhaps the software upgrade improved this
I get two days out of a charge and it recharges in 30 – 40 minutes
Only a couple of gripes:The camera is great in daylight but becomes progressively grainier in low light, but that’s normal with a lot of digital cameras
I use a real cameraifI wantto get serious
The off / on button would be better on the opposite side as it’s possible to trigger shutdown while adjusting volume
Also the off/on button turns on the camera unintentionally sometimes
I find the gestures for flashlight and camera to be of questionable use so I turned that off
Overall I’m thrilled at the value of this smartphone and could recommendit
Hit or miss.  Read if yours have random crash or restarts
I purchased this moto G plus 5(with Amazon ad) when it was on sale with the lightning deal
It was straight forward to migrate from an iPhone 6 and I was up and running after some setup
The phone was snappy
No issues whatsoever
The only cons I saw were the camera (slow and delayed) and smaller screen size(I prefer a bigger screen than what it is)
But hey, for what I paid , it is a very capable and adequate phone
The frequency of restarts was tolerable maybe once every other day
I noticed the restarts were getting more frequent and annoying and was debating what to do
Googled around and found this to be a common problem
I tried putting it on safe mode to troubleshoot but decided not to because I hadto use some of the apps during the day
I decided to get a replacement from Amazon and got the new phone within 2 days
I set up the new phone with exact same apps and setup and config
It's been over 3 weeks and the phone hasn't restarted ot crashed once
I'm really happy with the phone
To summarize, these g5 plus could be hit or miss
If applicable you might want to try to exchange for another
Battery life is excellent , snappy and running Android 7

These can't be and shouldn't be compared with top of the line Samsung or iPhone

Over 2 months in, I love it!
I purchased the Moto G4 when it came out and after about 10 months or so I started getting a pretty bad ghost touching problem
So after getting almost a full year out of the G4I went ahead replaced it with a G5 plus
Before the ghost touching issue, I loved everything about my G4, so much so that I thought I'd give the G5 (I partially blamed myself for the ghost touching as I am very hard on a phone)
I'm a few months in and so far I couldn't be happier

There are a ton of reviews by pro's who can give you all the deep info, but as an everyday consumer I can tell you it does everything I need it to and I don't feel like I'm getting any less than the big brand phones (Iphone, Galaxy etc
From gaming to excellent google integration and moreI love this phone
I will say taking pictures at night is not very good at all, but highly lighted pictures are fantastic
Of course if I get the ghost touching again or any other major problem I'll let you know, but over 2 months in I love it

I’ve found that turning on my weather app’s current temperature setting on the notification bar works well to keep the ads from going full screen
There is also an ad widget that acts like an Amazon “ticker tape” of deals
I create an additional home screen, a screen I know I’ll never look at,and move the widget there
I've had this phone for a little more than 6 months now
Here is why I bought it and what I think about it
My wife and I travel a lot
She is from Ireland and we try to go twice a year to see her family
In one of those trips per year, we try to spring board over to other European countries as a side trip
As if having the privilege to go to Ireland isn't awesome enough, sauntering over to Europe every now and then is just down right exciting
The fly in the ointment:Not being able to take our mobile phone service with us
We use MetroPCS here in the States (what can I say, we're cheap
We don't like to pay $125+ for cell services when we can get away with paying $80 for both our lines
Even if we did go for your Verizon or AT&T GSM services, we're surely not going to pay for any worldwide roaming service
This is where the Moto G5 Plus comes in
It has the capacity and capability to work on a good number of cellular and broadband frequencies
All we do is buy a 20
00 EUD sim card in Ireland where mobile broadband and cell service is friendlier and cheaper to the masses (we get unlimited data for that 20 euros BTW)
Stick that SIM card in the phone and
We get to use our own phones
We even took this phone from Dublin to Germany last September
It was invaluable when trying to rendezvous with friends in foreign countries!Being able to text, or whatsapp, a friendly face/voice while in a strange place adds a bit of security
My only gripe with the US-based moto products is that they don't sell dual sim versions
But swapping out sim cards is not a back breaker
It takes all but 10 seconds
com to see if this phone will work in the country, and that country's carriers, of your liking
This phone is good, but I'm sure it has its limits)
Getting this kind of phone that can go far at this price is a steal!
Nearly perfect.  Should add wireless charging.

This is a step up in most areas: camera, battery life, screen, memory, and convenience (fingerprint, phone actions)
The price is stellar
Prime model, and the ads are pretty inconsequential
Only thing I miss is wireless charging, which is strangely a pretty substantial miss
Although wireless charging is very slow, it is ideal by the nightstand where you need to grab and set your phone without turning on lights and feeling around
And saves wear on the charging port and accidents in the car
I tried an external solution, but then you give up your fast charge port altogether
Going to try magnetic usb cables next, but what an unneeded expense for the lack of a couple of dollars in parts

I decided to give the Moto G Plus a chance after I found that my Nexus 6P was a bit too large for my hands
For my review I will be discussing the non-ads version
So far I've experienced zero performance issues
User Interface - The Moto G comes stock with Android 7
0 and uses an almost vanilla Android UI with almost no bloatware whatsoever
It has a couple options that are unique to Lenovo phones such as the option to swipe up to access your App drawer which I find very convenient
The UI is very clean and easy to use
Camera -12 MP rear facing/5 MP front facing
The picture quality has been top notch on every photo
Zero delay in shutter speeds
Display - 5
2 inch 1080p LCD screen that is super clear
The size of the phone is perfect for me
Memory - Other than the 64 GBs of memory this phone has an expandable SD card slot to give you up to 256 GBs of space
Battery - This is really a big plus for this device
The battery easily lasts all day
I text, surf the net and stream music/video throughout the day
I would consider myself a heavy user and yet by 8pm (I wake up at 4am so it gets used ALL day) I have 30%-40% left
The fast charge capability is amazing in that I can charge the phone for 20 minutes and recover 30%-40% in battery life
Finger Print Sensor - I really like the placement of the finger print sensor as well as the option to utilize multiple fingers
I use my thumb and index finger
You can also use the finger print sensor to open menus and open certain applications
Its pretty Plain Jane in appearance with a simply aluminum body
The major gripe I have with the body design is how far the camera protrudes out
It definitely sticks out a bit but this can be remedied by using a good case
Charger Type - Utilizing Micro USB versus the new USB standard (Type C) is kind of a pain considering I had already exchanged my Micro USB cables for the new standard
This is a minor gripe but I feel it should be included in my review
If you don't have the capital to buy a Google Pixel or Samsung S8 then definitely look into buying this phone
Between the design, UI and battery life I really feel its a top phone thats available today

Exceeds my high expectations!My Samsung S3 starting acting up so I did research for a new android smart phone that wouldn't cost a fortune
This phone caught my attention and I read many reviews about it
Having had it for a few weeks I am glad to report that it exceeds my expectations
One criticism I had read about it is it's weight
I actually like the solid feel, and although it is slightly heavier than I am used too, I like it like this
Once I got used to a newer android version I find the phone easy to maneuver and use
The large screen is great for viewing photos and video, and makes using the internet nice too!Sound is fine both with the ear and speaker phone
I have not used the phone for music, but I do like that it has an FM radio which I will use for sporting events
All in all I am very pleased with this phone and the price!
Amazing phone
This was an upgrade for me from last years Moto G4 Play and it is honestly the best phone I have ever had
It runs fast and smooth
I am honestly stunned by the number of apps that can be open and this phone still zips quickly with my finger
The resolution is stunning and videos and pictures shine
The speaker works great on phone calls and is really good for playing music or videos on those rare times you don't have earbuds or a bluetooth speaker
On many calls at times the person on the other end would not be able to hear me
The call didn't drop but I would have to look at the screen and press things till they could hear me again
This issue was me totally and not the phone at all
I have never had a phone this big and am used to pressing the phone against my face so the microphone was close to my mouth
I needed to do this in the past with smaller phones like the Moto G4 Play
Once I learned how to hold this phone correctly no problems at all
The bluetooth connection and internet connection all works great as well
I totally love the finger sensor and use it as the main source of maneuvering on the phone
It works flawlessly, is fully receptive and I have been using this phone 6 weeks thus far
I also find the camera and the quality of its pictures to be quite good and videos that I take shine

I bought the Amazon Prime version with adswhich did not bother me but at the beginning of this month when Amazon announced they would be removing ads from all Amazon prime phones for free I was ecstatic
It is not done through an update
Look on Amazon how to do it or ask google or seriously call Amazon support
It was so easy to do and now my phone is ad free
As is my last year Moto G4 Play
I had a Blu Prime phone 2 years ago and paid the $50 to have the ads removed
Amazon gave me back that $50 as an my Amazon Gift Card credit
For a phone I bought 2 years ago and don't even use anymore!! Thank yo Amazon
I see a lot of negative reviews lately with people complaining about the ads
Amazon will remove them for free people!! And if you think the phone is faulty in some way remember this is an advanced phone
Scroll up the apps and the Device Help has all the help you need
The near Android stock version that runs on this phone is great
As you can see I am beyond thrilled with this phone
It may sound like someone actually paid me to write this review but it is just honest me trying to find a flaw with it and I just can't
Honestly I have never used a phone for so much other than calls and texting till this one
Now you can't get me off of it
Now any phone I get in the future has a hard act to follow
I am irritated by so many negative reviews that aren't based on facts
If you are considering this phone look at those reviews and see if those seem to be valid faults with the phone or people not wanting to learn how to use their phone
Go to the high reviews and read the in depth reviews of how great this phone is
I highly recommend
Enjoy this amazing phone!Also lastly I use AT&T and get 4G LTE service all the time
Thanks for reading and hope I helped you make a decision on this phone

Great Value and Features
I have held off on reviewing this phone until the honeymoon period was over and it lost its new phone feel
I will start off by saying, I have the Prime version and have not found the ads to be annoying or overly intrusive
With that out of the way,
This phone has an amazing boot animation with shows off the color depth and range of the screen
Setting it up was easy, like you would expect and without any hiccups
I was coming from a Moto X Pure so I had some expectation of being under-whelmed by the phone
The Moto Gestures are still in the UI, chop for flashlight, twist for camera and the Moto Display is still there
At first I was a little disappointed with the 5
2 screen, because I felt I was losing some screen real estate coming from the X Pure
5 back, when I turned on the One Button Nav
Once you get used to using the One Button features and gestures, going back to on screen buttons feels very awkward and cumbersome
The one almost complaint I would have about the phone, is that you have to be very particular when selecting an SD card if you want the phone to use it as internal memory
I thought I had picked out a card which was fast enough, however I kept getting various application errors and would sometimes have issues with the devices I had Bluetooth connections with
This phone would have to be one of the best mid-range devices on the market at the moment
And for the price, with or with out the Prime ads, it is a great value for the money
One thing the buyer should be aware of, is that Moto/Lenovo seems to have gotten behind on their security patches and software updates
So if this is important for you, it might be something to consider
The unit I have, is still running Android 7
I have to say the camera takes really good pictures, especially for this price point
While it does have the same sensor as another flagship phone, do not expect it to take flagship level pictures
But it is a great phone for the price
Keep in mind this is a budget phone
But it is a great phone for the price
Love that it works on gsm and cdma

I've worked in the mobile industry for many years and this is all the phone you need

It cracked the tempered glass protector I had and bent the whole phone about 3mm over its length
So I went to buy a new one and could not

I contacted Amazon via Chat, told them the whole story, and they offered to send me a brand new device
I reiterated that the device was not defective and that it was my fault

Five stars for this phone and five stars for Amazon
Amazing battery life
I'm used to my phone dying on me and being on a charger multiple times a day
I took it on a 6 hour road trip and let the screen on with the map the entire time, never depleted any battery
Forgot to take the charger out of my car and still had about 60% the next morning
Charged it on the car while using maps again and was able to fully charge it during my drive
The battery life on this is phenomenal
The camera is can either be really amazing or just ok

The ads on the lock screen don't bother me at all and I already had most of the Amazon apps installed ony previous devices so the preinstalls didn't​ bother me either, especially for the decent discount you get

Perfect phone for my Mom, compares nicely with my Moto X Pure Edition
Very Impressed
I picked this up to replace a Moto G second edition that I had purchased for my mother
I was a little worried that she might not easily be able to navigate the one touch button in comparison to the soft key button that were at the bottom of her screen on her old phone

I was surprised to see that there was an option to use the phone in either mode by disabling the one touch button in the moto settings app, which essentially shrunk the screen slightly to make room for the old style soft key buttons

When I showed my 71 year old mother the difference between the two options she decided to try navigating with the single button and a few days into using her phone has decided that she likes it better than having the three other soft keys always displayed
I wasn't aware of how the single button worked until setting the phone up
She didn't want to fool around with setting up the fingerprint scanner, so I can't report on that feature
In December of 2016 I gave up the ghost on my original Moto X and picked up a Moto X Pure Edition while they were on sale through a big box store for $249
I had the new Moto G5 Plus for a couple of days to set up some screen widgets and get all of my Mother's accounts set up before giving it to her
I'm on AT&T in Central NY and the new Moto G5 plus was able to speedtest faster than my MXPE while connected to a LTE signal
Side by side and tested at the same time, my MXPE had an LTE download speeed of 42Mbps, while the Moto G5 Plus was faster at 56Mbps
The same advantage didn't happen connected to WiFi at my home
Neither of us found the Amazon ad screen an issue when unlocking the phone
I had read in another review that a user was easily able to remove the pre-installed Amazon Android apps, but that wasn't what I found
In comparison to her Moto G second edition, my Mom says that the call quality is better on the G5 Plus, something she didn't realize until using the new phone
Bottom Line, it was well worth the $60 savings to buy the Amazon version and my Mom not only loves her new phone, but has easily adapted to the one touch button
Be a good son, buy your Mom the Moto G5 Plus

Hi everyone
Moto G5 Plus...just can't be beat in the value arena
I am a long time Moto G user (Moto 3, 4, and now 5) and also had the Moto E early on
This phone feels like an evolution for the line (understanding this phone is geared to the value price point) that meets the necessary needs and a lot of the wants for most customers
I am not a heavy user but use my phone for checking emails, surfing, streaming videos, music, purchases, GPS, pics, and games (the free kind)

For Moto to include the processor and RAM at this price point (took advantage of Amazon Prime deal of course!) with HD screen, strong battery life, finger print scanner, and ergonomic set up; shows they know what the mass mobile user really wants and cares about
I won't lament the camera (there are plenty of tech reviews out) but will say; for the person who wants to capture the moment or record family events; this device does more than adequate
Nothing like this is perfect, so there are some compromises; e
Contrary to what the tech community says, the public at large does not care about Type C charging; especially since this phone has a turbo charger
If you do not care about a $800+ feeling phone with camera to match, you CAN'T go wrong with this phone
I think the screen is great and battery life is even better
All of my smartphone experience was with iPhones, from the 4 on (had 4, 5, and 6)
No real problems switching to Android with this phone
Most of my complaints are features of Android so can't fault Moto or this phone for those
Coming from the iPhone 6, I think the screen is great and battery life is even better
Camera not quite as nice though definitely adequate for a phone
The amazon ads aren't bad at all
I'm so used to seeing ads while browsing the web that I generally don't see them anywhere
Only negative thing with the ads is you have to tap the fingerprint scanner twice in order to fully open the phone to the home screen
Without the ads it would be a single press to get to the home screen
I do really like the fingerprint scanner with the gestures built in to go back or open up recent apps
That's definitely nice to free up a little extra screen space

While the phone does come with Android 7, it does still say it's the security patch from Jan 1 2017 and I'd figure there should be more frequent updates than every 5+ months but maybe that's the old iPhone user in my head talking
Overall a great phone that does everything I need it to do while costing $500 less than a flagship phone from Apple or Samsung or Google
I just can't see myself paying those prices anymore when mid(-price)-range phones like this are so good

Update September 2017:
Original review:I am still getting familiar with this cellphone
Sure you can use the white balance, but then you might lose some of the sharpness in your photo (in the sky, for instance)
I like Google Voice and use it often for asking about the weather, searching for a song, or finding a business phone number, for example
Addressing the 4GB of RAM - the settings show the average amount of RAM used
So far the phone is fast and responsive for wifi and data
I still like using my Samsung Galaxy S5 for photos in addition to this cellphone
Both phones havetheir pluses and minuses for camera features
The Moto G5 screen is shiny and has a lot of glare and it's dark, so it's very hard to view in bright sunlight
When taking photos, I am often merely pointing and shooting and hoping for a good outcome
Maybe there is a setting change that will adjust for this
The photos came out fine, but using the 16x9 9-megapixel feature, cropping and zooming can result in very blurry photos
Also the selfie front camera takes clear photos, but there is distortion due to a wide angle lens, so you end up with a fun snapshot, not a great photo by any means
The nice thing about the selfie feature is that the camera blurs all skin imperfections - like a beauty mode
One negative so far is that the head phone jack seems a little stubborn with certain mp3 cords or headphones
As others have commented, the speaker is not very loud
Editing photos also serves to enhance the quality, but on occasion making changes seems to take forever
Update - Nov 29, 2017: I have now been using this phone on a very regular basis since I purchased it in July of 2017

After I decided that the S7 was unacceptable, I had a dilemma
I somehow missed all the deals for the Moto Z Play, but the Moto G5 Plus launched recently, and uses the same chipset
Compared with the Moto Z Play, the Moto G5 Plus has:Smaller screen (5

LCD screen vs AMOLED screen (no question, AMOLED screens are superior!)Smaller battery (3000mAH vs 3510 mAH)No Moto Mods (no big deal --- as of date there are no Moto Mods worth the price or weight or bulk)Lighter (156g vs 165g)Different camera (can't tell whether it's any better or worse, just different)4GB RAM (vs 3GB)64GB storage (vs 32GB storage)micro-USB vs USB C (this is a feature as far as I'm concerned --- no need to buy new cables!)No full-time OK Google
I bought the phone and got the free same day shipping
After the setup, the phone was fast! Browsing, e-mail, and even taking pictures is reasonably fast with next to no lag
Sound quality and bluetooth seemed to work better than my 2015 Moto G, which would get audio stutter whenever a music player was being asked to multi-task with any other app
And wow, storage! I didn't realize how constricted I'd been until I started installing apps and after more than 100 apps on the system the device still proclaimed that I had used only 6
71 on the internal storage
Note that both Moto Z Play and the Moto G5 Plus have headphone jacks, which is very nice since one of our cars and many of our high quality audio headphones still use the traditional system
The physical device feels slippery (I have no idea why anyone thinks that metal is superior to plastic for devices that you need to handle)
I thought the fingerprint scanner would be a gimmick, but it's turned out to be quite reasonable
Battery life has been nothing short of incredible, coming from both the S7 and the Moto G 2015
All in all, I'll be keeping the phone for a while

Just Buy It Already! ***Updated 6/1/18***
I was heart broken when I shattered the screen on my first gen Moto X a few years ago
I decided I would not only go back to the iPhone (this was after a few months of trying to decide what phone I wanted) but I would get the Plus
I grew to love my Plus, but all the while, I longed for my X
A week ago today, an ad for the G5 Plus popped up on my Instagram feed
I read a few online reviews (there weren't a ton) and then decided to see it in person at Best Buy the next day
I pretty much used the phone for about 30 seconds when I knew I would wind up buying it

I went back home, researched a bit more on the discounted Prime version, and ordered my phone!Here's my thoughts after a week:This phone looks, feels, and performs like the secret love child of my Moto X and 6S Plus
The size is a perfect fit between the two
The system is snappy fast like the iPhone, the experience is almost pure Android like my X
What you get for the price
so worth it
This is my 4th Amazon device with ads, and by far the least obtrusive
I sometimes forget I even have the ads
I was REALLY set on paying full price, but decided to try the Prime one-I'm glad I did!I picked up a screen protector and 128G micro sd with the savings
All I did was popped my sim card into my G5 Plus from my 6S Plus and that was all-immediate service
Calls and signal have been normal
just buy it!! :)***Update 6/1/18***Last summer, I wound up getting an iphone 7 with an added line
I transferred my number to the iPhone as my daily user, and then my Moto G5 Plus would be a back up phone
In November, I started doing delivery via an app based service
I decided since I had the Moto just laying around, why not use it, and save the wear and tear on my iPhone?Well, using the Moto for work is what has prompted this update
My shifts are anywhere from 1-4 hours, and pretty consistent usage of in app navigation, plus camera usage, and flash if applicable
Sometimes I work two shifts a day
I generally work 5-6 days a week, with a two week break in January of this year (2018)
So basically this means I having been using my Moto daily since last November
I have a thin case that is more for grip than protection
Up until about a month ago, I've always had a screen protector on it
I decidedly do not like holding this phone without a case, and I like the case I have enough this is a non issue
I have also dropped this phone so many times, it's unreal
And some of the drops have been since I went screen protector free
The phone has definitely knicked and surface scratched here and there, but no major breaks, cracks or any such thing
And more importantly, no performance issues due to internal shock
I have the 64 GB, and it always does what's asked
It's just consistent, it's absolutely fast enough for day to day life
I never find myself annoyed with it for lagging or such
I don't use the phone for calls or texting, but I do have Facebook, Messenger, Instagram, solitaire, soduko, etc on there
It's not just a work specific phone anymore, as I often use it to watch video or browse the web
I love the picture on my iPhone 7, and the size for pocketability, but in terms of screen, the Moto is perfect for me
It's comfortable for me to hold, and I feel the screen size is more than adequate for viewing movies, shows, etc
I also have a Fire Tablet 7, which I love, but I've found myself going back to my Moto more often
Another thing-this phone has been in the shower
It's been rained on
It's all but been full on submerged, with zero issues
While I'm not reckless with my things, I'm not super careful either-life happens!I've recently been interested in the new G6, and then the X4
After comparing specs (I don't recall seeing anymore 64GB options in this price range) and playing with the X4 in person, I realize that the 64GB G5 is a bit of a treasure to be held on to
While there are definitely better camera's on phones out there, this one is no slouch
If you learn to work with it's quirks, you can get some great shots
Another thing is battery life
I've tried using my iPhone for deliveries, but a shift will drain about 75% of my battery
That same length of shift about take about 25-30% of the Moto's battery
And the Moto gestures-being able to karate chop my flashlight on is invaluable when I'm out working
One 'downside' is that my phone being a Prime phone is not getting the Android updates in a timely manner (well, at all as of this writing)
I think it's still on 7
I enjoy my iPhone for it's nicely organized widgets, and interaction with my Apple Watch, but the Moto wins me over with an experience that I just connect with

If you are cross shopping this phone with an X4 or G6, and you can snag this one (specifically a 64GB) cheaper than those two, I would pick the G5 (unless you REALLY want the dual camera and other features)
I've also found myself using Google Assistant more often (I do with you could wake it from the lock screen, but no, you can't
I'm pretty entrenched in the Google and Amazon worlds, so the Moto really works for me in that aspect also
And really, all in all, it just works for me, period!!
This phone makes me so happy!

Keep making phones like this Moto!!!------This phone makes me so happy!Pros: 4GBs ram, 64GB storage, 128GB Micro SD, super fast fingerprint sensor AND STOCK ANDROID N! It's a no brainer for around $250

I decided to give this a go as a budget Android phone
Our family is solidly in the iOS camp, but I had been curious about what Android had to offer
I brought this phone and got it hooked up through Verizon without any issues - I was in and out of the Verizon store in about 10 minutes (we already had a Verizon account with other devices on it)
In general, the phone is just fine
Battery life is great, and performance is fine
It's not as snappy as an iPhone 6s or 7 - scrolling in web pages, and games like Pokémon Go just take longer to load and stutter a bit more
But it gets the job done

I'm not a fan of the power switch being BELOW the volume rocker - the phone is relatively large, and when holding it, your thumb fairly naturally rests on the power switch, which isn't all that useful
The fingerprint reader works well, and the Motorola app allows programming of the reader to do a 'back' and 'home' command, freeing up some screen space, which is cool

I turned off the long-press on the fingerprint reader to turn off the device, because it was far to easy to turn the phone off - the 'long press' must be like a second - I found myself accidentally turning the phone off far too often
Out of the box with Android 7, there's no way to tell if you have unread e-mails - the apps don't have 'badges'
Coming from iOS, this is hugely annoying
I know in some cases this can be restored with a change of launder and a bunch of configuration, but it's a crappy annoyance to deal with
Supposedly this might be fixed in the new version of Android
Not the fastest in the world, but it doesn't well enough for normal use
Good battery life, good build quality, nice screen, and all of the pro's and con's of Android
Once last comment - I don't find the Amazon stuff too intrusive
By default there is a widget set up to show Amazon sales, but it is easily removed like any other widget
Once you do that, the only real Amazon thing that is forced on you is an add on the unlock screen - not a biggie

The display is a bit small for my taste, the fingerprint reader placement is on the front of the phone
The aluminum shell is a step above previous moto devices
The phone is quick, but not nearly the fastest phone I've ever used
The phone is a near vanilla android experience, which many users will welcome, but updates are much slower and less frequent under Lenovo ownership
The Moto G5+ has the popular gesture features to operate the camera and flash (as a light)
The flash is very bright and makes a great flashlight if in need, but the camera is mediocre at best
It works, but the quality of the pictures is a noticeable step below high end phones
The battery life has been great
A day of moderate use from 7am-10pm puts me at 40-50% life remaining, and heavy use 20-30%
If you're a prime member or heavy amazon user, the phone comes preloaded with amazon apps including Prime Video
The apps cannot be installed, but can be disabled
The fingerprint reader works OK
If you fingers get even slightly damp/sweaty or slightly dirty you have to wipe off the glossy reader and your fingers
Sometimes the reader gets disabled and you have to use the backup pw/pin (seemingly at random)
The speaker is adequate for calls, but not music
You will need a speaker or headphones
A headphone jack is on the bottom, and works as expected
Bluetooth connectivity has been great between my soundbar, car, and speaker
The phone works on every major US carrier (and the MVNOs), which makes switching between carriers a breeze
The phone does lack Beam/NFC for the USA version, and the built in screen casting only works with google devices (chromecast)

Update on Verizon Experience:Needed to use the phone in Europe

Called Verizon, my current carrier, as I noticed that the phone was not identified as a Moto G5 Plus on my account and online it would not let me add the best rate for International ($10/day fee that you only pay if you use the phone data/voice service)
After many long conversations with Verizon, bottom line is they told me this phone would not work in Europe
Went to the T-Mobile store,got a SIM with a new phone number and plan completely worked with the phone in Europe
They send you a text as soon as you turn it on to spell out terms for where you are at
You can enable a feature that uses Wifi for telephone calls when you are on WiFi, so that you avoid the only real charge they have (20 cents/minute for voice)
Data worked well
They do disable HotSpot/Tethering when you are in Europe, but WiFi is pretty much everywhere so was not an issue for my other devices
This phone is great, the only limitations come from the carriers

Great phone but issues with Verizon and Dialing
So I screwed up my Samsung S5 and needed a quick replacement
I got this phone and then has some issues getting it to work with Verizon
I went to a Verizon store as I needed to get a smaller SIM than my S5's SIM
They told me that this wasn't compatible with their network but then mentioned that if I go to a Verizon corporate store, they might be able to get it to work
This made no sense to me but because the Amazon website said that this would work with Verizon (and I didn't want to deal with returning the phone) I decided to try the corporate store
Sure enough, they were able to get it to work
So YES, it does work with Verizon
After this I tried to use the Verizon Cloud to restore the settings from my previous phone onto this phone
this is not a Verizon phone so Verizon claims that the cloud will not work with this phone (not convinced that this is true yet, sometimes you just have to talk to a different person)
So I had to find alternative ways to transfer files, messages, logs, etc
So then I got the phone up and running, then I starting noticing that my voice calls had crackle in them
The person on the other side could hear me fine but their voice was crackled on my end
I looked though websites and found that a lot of phones were having this issue
I was ready to send it back again but then I decided to try a phone call on Viber
That came in crystal clear
So I determined that it wasn't the phone, it was the sorry dialer app
I changed the app to a different app and my calls seem to be working
this is where I am at right now
The phone seems great but Verizon sucks as always (though I have had them for 10+ years) and the dialer app sucks
will write more as this saga continues
may still send the phone back as it shouldn't have had the crackle issue
Others haven't had that issue
maybe it is a defective unit
to be continued

the cost is about $150 to replace a battery that goes bad in this Motorola phone
I bought this phone in May of 2017 (on Amazon)
It is now July of 2018 (14 months later) and the phone battery needs replacing - it won't keep a charge for two hours now
I just called Motorola support and they told me the battery cannot be replaced,Since the warranty period is one year, they told me they would replace my phone for $125, plus $24
99 if I want them to send a phone to me before I send mine to them
In the end, the cost is about $150 to replace a battery that goes bad in this Motorola phone, if it is over one year old
Be aware of this before buying this phone

I love my new phone!
but I was annoyed enough by the limitation of stock Android that I ...
Full -I was a cheapskate and decided to buy the Amazon Prime exclusive version to save $60
If you're okay with stock Android and you don't care about playing with settings, there's nothing wrong with that edition
They full screen when you have no notifications, and slot in as the last notification slot if you do
Once you unlock the phone, they're gone until the next lock screen
The only real modifications Moto has made to Android for this phone are built into a special Moto app, which allows a couple of tweaks

The main settings concern inertial gestures (which allow you to open the camera or turn on the flashlight by moving the phone in certain ways), and fingerprint gestures (which replace the intrusive software navigation bar with swiping left for back, right for recents, or tapping for home)
You can also disable the obnoxious boot sound
Everything in this app is great, they did a really good job in centralizing the non-standard tweaks and making them actually useful
The rest of the Android experience is pretty stock
The launcher is a slightly modified version of the Pixel Launcher, where they've only put a custom lock screen in and made the app drawer transparent, both of which are tasteful
All of the other settings are basic Nougat, which makes the interface very efficient
As far as hardware goes,the battery life is unbelievable
I've yet to see less than around half charge by the end of a day, it lasts forever
Turbo charging is also a nice feature, and lets you emergency charge your phone quickly when you only have access to power for a short period of time
No NFC, but that's pretty typical of a mid-range phone, and I don't really miss it
I'm never going to run out of RAM or storage (4GB/64GB model)
The graphics processor is very zippy and keeps up with that octa-core processor nicely
I've noticed no lag under really any circumstances
The camera's nice, pretty on par with what's available in the rest of the market, and not much to be said about it
The brightness and color of the dual-tone flash comes through well on the camera, and makes for a very visible flash light
The screen is nice, good contrast in the sun, and dim enough at night that I don't blind myself
It's only full HD, not 4K, to give those of you who like to text with a microscope something to complain about, but for us mere mortals the resolution is perfect
The radios are sensitive and reliable
I get LTE with decent consistency in my apartment, where my old Zenfone 2 couldn't with the same SIM
I like having dual-band WiFi, as I can finally put everything on my 5 GHz network and clear up some 2
4 GHz interference
There's no Wireless-AC, but how much are you really downloading on your phone?Bluetooth has been pretty reliable, nothing out of the ordinary
I've now switched up to the standard version (which I only booted on stock Android long enough to toggle the developer switch for bootloader unlocking), and running AOKP, I couldn't be happier

The extra features that really make this phone nice for me were theming, the ability to tether (this is a carrier limitation for me which can be overridden with aftermarket ROMs), and manual control of whether to use LTE or 3G since I drive for work and end up in some places with weird reception
If none of these are important to you, there's no reason you'll be disatisfied with this phone

It's probably the best phone you can get in this price range, and with the cross-network compatibility, you don't have to worry about switching carriers if you move (this is rumored to also take 2 SIM cards, with one supplanting the SD card, but I've yet to try)
Whatever you need from a phone, you can achieve on this hardware, and you'll be hard-pressed to find anything much better shy of the $500+ range

This is a tough review to write at this time
Let me start by saying I love the features of the phone and how smooth they work
The fingerprint reader is a major improvement to my Samsung Note 4, and it is nice to not have all the bloatware
The camera is good for the price of the phone and I love the near stock Android
The screen is good for the price
it is by no means AMOLED comparable but I really don't notice
The fingerprint button doubling as a multifunction home button is amazing
The features, in combination with 4 GB of RAM and 64 GB of internal storage plus the micro SD card capability sound like a no-brainer for $240 and should all but guarantee a 5 star review
My data does not work in Mexico using my Verizon plan
This was never an issue with my Note 4 not with my wife's Pixel
While Verizon is partly to blame, I feel somewhat duped that the phone is advertised as certified as fully compatible with Verizon
I've heard it all from Verizon from the world phone excuse to them admitting it is simply because I didn't buy the phone from them
I had the phone for 2 weeks before it decided to BRICK out of nowhere and for no good reason
I was looking at my phone waiting for my second morning alarm to go off, when the Moto boot up screen makes a surprise appearance
The phone then proceeds to shut down and never turn on properly again
The battery was just about 80% and the phone had been in a Incipio case and had withstood absolutely zero damage of any sort in it's 2 week life
I was able to get the Fastboot screen and it said the battery status was OK
But the phone wouldn't boot in regular mode, safe mode, factory reset
the chances of getting 2 defective phones are slim, I will be living in rear of a random bricking after my return period is up
This results in a permanent one star loss that Motorola/Lenovo won't get back
Obviously I feel the phone is worth the value and the risk at the price of $240
Albeit the phone doesn't work 100% properly with Verizon

Fantastic deal of a device. .
Mine arrived on Mar 31st (first day of release) and had it activated on Cricket Wireless (AT&T)
Hardware Impressions:--The Moto G5 Plus arrived in a tiny package, which contained the phone, a charger, USB cable and a tool for opening the SIM card/SD card tray
--The phone feels very light
--The protruding camera in the back is something that initially feels weird and will probably take some getting used to
--Both the volume up/down and power button are on the same side (right side) and clustered fairly close together
--Device came with 80% of battery charge
--Display is sharp, bright and clear
--The sim card tray is, in a word, weird
The other bummer has to do with the Amazon Prime Exclusive version--one of the nano sim card slots has been physically blocked
--The power button is used to turn off the display (short press), or, upon long press, to power off the device
Initial Setup:Supplied two credentials--one for the gmail account and another for Amazon
All Google related app settings got restored fully as well, including things like Chrome favorites, music library, Google Drive contents, Photos albums and pictures, etc, etc
Amazon Prime Exclusive Info:1
All of these can be DISABLED but not uninstalled, it seems
This might be a boon to folks who like to shop on Amazon
Overall Impressions [Updated April 9th]:After ten days with the device, I'm maintaining the rating of 4 stars
From Google Maps to Chrome, haven't seen any delays

Great phone
For people complaining that you can't use the fingerprint scanner to skip the lockscreen ads
Good battery life on Nougat, but lacking some standard features like notification LED.
Heard all the hype for Nougat and not a fan, simple things annoy me, like tying ring and notification volumes together
I do not like loud chiming in my ear for an email or message when I need to have ringer on full blast, people next to me can hear it when have bluetooth in my ear, they turn their heads

Camera has no image stabilization, always tells me I am moving and the pictures come out blurry, well about 50% of them anyhow much more than the LG G4 I came from which was difficult to take a bad picture with
No notification LED, so unless you wake up your phone you will not know if anyone had messaged you if you step out of range with bluetooth in or you put your phone into silent mode, etc
It does wake up screen for a split second, so unless you have your phone tipped at some angle you can constantly see the screen and you stare at your phone, you may miss messages, emails, etc

All in all it is a good 'budget' phone though, apps run quickly n smoothly, the Prime advertisements are not annoying and the battery will last a couple days with minimal use, taking a dozen pics, it uploading to drive due to me not turning feature off, my posting to Facebook, turning off notifications for FB, being in fringe area where phone typically get drained trying to connect to a tower, making and receiving a dozen calls, after 2 days phone still over 50% which is as good, or better than the higher priced flagship phone I came from
Hopefully enough users will complain about the features of Nougat and they send out an update, but M is already n the works, so they will likely just jump to another OS without much improvements

My previous daily carry was a Moto X Pure Edition, on Republic Wireless

I couldn't pass up the Prime Day deal on this phone, even though I didn't need a new phone, and I actually decided to bite the bullet and have my first unrooted Android device!I like Amazon anyways, and thought the Amazon ad version would be okay, and I actually like seeing the deals on the lockscreen
I was double-tapping the fingerprint sensor when I first got it, but now I take my time and actually read the offers

This phone is missing things I really like on the Pure (waking up the phone with a wave, touchless Google Now, those awesome stereo speakers and better camera, and the huge, beautiful display), but the Moto G Plus is definitely speedy enough for me, and I LOVE the fingerprint sensor
the swiping to go back and seeing recents is awesome!And I usually take pictures outside anyways, and I'm really pleased with the quality

the twist to open the camera and double chop to get the flashlight are great
I honestly think my favorite part of going from the Pure to the G5 Plus is the weight difference
the Pure is SO heavy
I'm really enjoying the difference in my pocket!And even though this is mostly plastic, it certainly feels sturdy and well built
It was easy to swap out the Republic Wireless GSM SIM card from the Pure to the G5 Plus, and I was ready to go in minutes, so the phone has been working great so far
I've had a bunch of Moto phones now, back to the Droid X, and I've been really happy with them, and it's nice to have something I can own outright that's not $800
it's worth it for me to lose some of the bells and whistles, especially when I get the itch for something new!So this really was perfect for me
I gave this 5 stars because of the value quotient, not because it's the most powerful phone out there, of course

It does pretty much everything I want, with all the sensors I like (I never used NFC, so I don't miss that), and man, that fingerprint sensor is awesome!I liked reading the reviews of this processor being very efficient too, and love having the 4GB of RAM to hopefully get a nice amount of life out of it for a few years

The Moto G5 Plus Has a Lot to Like at a Price that Made Me Smile
I’d been keeping my eye on this phone from the Amazon started advertising it back in April
My S5 had become a problem child- rebooting itself during calls is just one example of its recent bad behavior
I looked at the new shiny phones- the Galaxy S8 and the Google Pixel, but I just couldn’t bring myself to pay what amounted to a nice weekend away with my wife
And I didn’t want to lease one for the next few years
Amazon had a one day deal on the Moto G5 Plus where I could get the phone (4 gigs ram and 64 gigs storage) and a case for under 200 dollars
After another hour or two of indecision, I finally clicked the button and my new phone was on the way
The first things you need to keep in mind is what this phone is, and what it is not
Comparing Moto G5 Plus to a Pixel or a S8is like comparing a new Mazda 6 to a Tesla
You are not buying the latest high-end phone that comes with a butler who’ll carry it securely in his white gloves
But you are not buying a low end phone made of coconuts, connected to other coconuts with a string
The Moto G5 Plus is somewhere in the middle
What I like:-The Price:What’s not to like about a new phone under $200, unlocked, that’s so far met all my needs
The price also lets me not worry about my phone all that much
Breaking a 200 dollar phone doesn’t feel as bad as breaking, or losing, an 800 dollar phone
-It Connects to What I Need it to Connect to:I am on Sprint and haven’t had an issue yet
Also no issues with wireless or bluetooth connections- in fact it seems I have gotten better and faster bluetooth connections with this phone than with the S5
-The Battery Is Very Impressive:I know it is new and will fade with time (don’t we all?)
But right now I charge it and night and don’t charge it again until the next night
The only drawback of the long life of this batter is I really haven’t had a chance to test out the 15 minute turbo charge as of yet
-The Screen Looks Nice:Crisp and clear and I can see it better in the light of a bright day than I could my S5 screen
-It Looks and Feels Like a Quality Phone
It doesn’t seem like they skimped on the build quality
And with the exception of the camera lens, it looks great
-It has Android 7
I am not even sure when my S5 last updated, but I really am liking the latest version of Android
-The Notification Screen
So I have read many people miss the blinky notification light- I really haven’t
Instead of the light (which said you had something but you didn’t know what) the Moto G5 Plus lock screen shows your notifications
I know it is a preference thing- but I like it better than the winky-blinky light
-It is Fast
Yes I am coming from a phone that had a lot less ram, as well as other issues, but this phone loads apps fast
-It has Gestures
Somewhat corny, but nothing like doing a tomahawk chop to turn on the lights or flip of the wrist to turn the camera on
Stuff that doesn’t bug me, but might bug you:-The Amazon Adds
Seriously not a big deal for me
The ads appear as just another notification (sometime a full screen add) on the unlock screen
I will gladly ignore these ads to pay a little less and if they do start to bug me, i can pay Amazon to remove them
-The Camera
This is one area where you can see a difference between the flag ships and this phone (or so I have been told- I have not hands on experience with these phones)
In good light the camera works fine and takes good photos- the focus is very responsive
But in low light you can get some grainy shots
I haven’t played enough with the settings to see how much this can be corrected, but my guess is this may be a place they skimped to keep the price down and there might not be a lot to do about it
As my phones have always been just a back up camera, I can live with the low light limitation
Stuff that Bugs Me-The Camera Lens Juts Out
I am a klutz and this is definitely something I could smack and scratch a lot
While a case remediates this problem, I would hope future designs would not have it sticking out so far
-Head Jack is on the Bottom of the Phone next to the usb port
It hasn’t caused any issues, but just feels wrong to me
-Volume and Power Buttons on the Same Side
I will get use to it, but I have hit the wrong button quite a few times in the past week
-I Can’t Take Out the Battery

So this may not be that big of a deal, but it bugs me- possibly due to the fact that I needed to remove my battery on a regular basis to either: cool down my S5 or do a hard reboot on it when it froze up
If the Moto G5 Plus doesn’t overheat or freeze up in a way I can’t restart it, I may get over this item
Bottom line, this phone has done everything I have needed it to, do without a problem, and I am happy with my purchase
Only time will tell how long it hold up- it could become like my S5 in a few years- but if I get a few good years out of it for the price I have paid, I will have no complaints what so ever
Over all I have found the Moto G5 Plus to provide the functionality I need at a price that makes me smile

Excellent phone
This phone is fast, powerful, and the battery is a significant upgrade
I owned the lg g3 at launch, so my comparison will be to that phone
Generally I use my phone for playing music over bluetooth (whenever I'm not asleep), browsing the web, and occasionally watching videos or playing games
Through average usage, I got about 4 days of battery life
On my G3 I was barely getting one-two days
When looking at the specs, this phone hasa smaller and lower-resolution screen than my g3
Luckily the phone allows you to bind the fingerprint scanner at the bottom to the navigation buttons
This frees up the whole screen of the phone
The G3 is about as fast as a phone needs to be, and this phone is faster than it
I've seen video comparisons, and this phone is maybe milliseconds in speed differences with the leading flag-ship phones of 2017
Not only is it fast, it stays cool even with all the apps that I generally use
I'd also like to mention that the back is metal, the sides are plastic, and the top bezel is fake chrome
The camera falls short of expectations in low-light photos, which means that there's definite noise
It also protrudes out of the phone, so cases are a must-have
This version also has Amazon ads, but they do not hinder my experience one bit
The ram on this phone is 1GB more than my G3, and I recommend having at least 3GB of ram even for general use
I believe that the speakers are average, and they are on the front
The volume rocker and power button are on the side, which is normal, but I prefer the g3's buttons on the back design
The buttons are plastic, and the power button is textured so you can tell it apart
The fingerprint scanner is durable and can withstand even knife scratches
If I were to compare this to the modern flagship phones, I'd say that you're not missing a whole lot on the specifications side of things
While this phone is extremely durable, the physical build does use plastic in a few areas
It also lacks water resistance, but it'll survive a splash or two if you're careful
A word of warning to those who plan to purchase the ad-version:You cannot root this phone
There is no expected root method for the ad-version within the next two years
You should also expect very few updates for the ad-version
That being said (as a rooted lg g3 owner), the resources provided by root are not necessary for every android user
Update - 1000 hours (powered on) into the phone, 9/2/2017So I've had this phone for awhile now
It feels like a flagship phone, even though it's not
I really like the shake to turn on the flashlight, and the twist to turn on the camera gestures
I still get great battery life out of it, and the speeds are excellent
Regarding the ads, they are no more annoying than lock screenI see them when I turn the screen on, and a swipe later, they're gone
I'm not missing root at all, but for longevity purposes, the lack of such a feature could still be considered a drawback

It's not a hardware issue, so I hope that it is fixed in the future

I have had this phone for about 6 months and if it weren't for a couple of (honestly acceptable) downsides, I would keep it forever
The camera is the biggest issue to me
It takes a decent picture but next to a Galaxy S6 or S7, it is not even in the ballpark
The low-light ability is not there and there is no image stabilization which is the biggest issue to me
The other issue for me is the display constantly lighting up when I don't want it to and not lighting up when I do!I don't understand it
It is supposed to light up when you nudge the phone but half the time I can pick it up and shake it violently and it doesn't
Then when I am riding in the car, it lights up over every single bump when I am not touching it
It drives me nuts
Those are the two main issues for me
Everything else about the phone makes it the best value phone I have ever had
It is cheap, running a good version of almost vanilla android, good responsiveness and decent speaker output
The earpiece volume is lacking however
The main reason I loved this phone is the battery life
I am not a heavy user but I leave bluetooth, location, and wi-fi on all the time and I consistently get 3-4 days out of a single charge
It is truly unbelievable
I will keep the Moto G5 in case I drop the S6 or something but I just need a better camera

Not up to expectations at all.
The Moto G5 plus is an absolute disappointment
The phone is plaiged with random reboots and just plain quirkinessThis was an upgrade from a Moto G4 that performed okay but not great
I also have a Lenovo tablet that I would rate just as poorly as the other two products
A new Android update came from Lenovo this week and the app crashes are worse
It gets a three start rating from me because it is a competent devise with a some very good attributes, but some pretty big shortcomings
I've had this phone for a month
It gets a three start rating from me because it is a competent devise with a some very good attributes, but some pretty big shortcomings, too
I would recommend this this phone for my 70 year old mother in a second, but it does not really get it done for me in a couple key ways
There are also better options for kids phones at a significantly better price point with some of the lower end Samsungs
For background, I switched to the Moto G Plus after using a Lumia 1020 Windows Phone for 4 years
I finally had to ditch the Windows phone because the operating system was not being updated and there no longer many supported apps
But overall the Lumina 1020was an excellent piece of hardware
Others in my household also have new top end Samsung and iPhones, so I am familiar with those
I bought the Moto G5 Plus because I did not want to shell out $800 for a new phone and the reviews here on this page were overall solid
I regret that now, however, and will be upgrading soon
Lots of calls, Facebook, email, you tube, various productivity apps
I can go pretty much 3 days between charges and when it needs it, the phone charges fast
My old Lumia needed to be charged frequently even when it was new and every night the iPhone and the Samsung Galaxy in my house are on their chargers or they are both bricks the next day
Not the Moto G Plus, but excellent batter life comes with some big tradeoffs
Processor speed
This is a harder one for me to evaluate since I was upgrading from a phone that was a couple generations old and running an antiquated OS, but this phone seems fast
I surf along with others in the family using higher end phones and don't seem to be noticeably behind and the performance well outpaces what I upgraded from
Size and dimensions
The Moto G5 Plus has a nice balance of size and shape
It has a large screen but is not too large to hold in your hand
The Moto G5 Plus does a good job connecting and staying connected to the Wi-Fi networks at my home and office
Fingerprint Sensor
I had low expectations for this at the start, but the fingerprint sensor works well and is not too touchy
All it takes is basically the same pressing motion you would have to turn on an iPhone, but with the added security of the fingerprint sensor built in
I work from home often and I actually talk on the phone quite a lot
The underwhelming phone quality is the main reason the Moto 5G Plus is not doing the job for me
This was a bit of an unpleasant surprise since I figured this would be a strength of the Motorola
I was slow to give up my old Motorola flip phone back in the day because It was a really good phone
Perhaps that element of their brand fell by the wayside with the Lenovo acquisition
The sound quality on calls is noticeably worse than my old Lumia, particularly when I use the speaker phone and it does not do a great job of filtering out background noise
The speaker/audio - Not good verging on awful
About the only thing this phone seems to play loud and clear is the annoying Hello Moto default ring tone
I could put my old Lumia on speaker and put it on the middle of a huge conference table at a meeting and it was as good as the hard wired speaker phone
It is very hard to hear the speaker in the car or anywhere with any background noise
Volume control as very little definition
it is pretty much on high (more or less) or silent
Cellular Signal Strength - Another surprising negative
I am using this unlocked phone on the AT&T LTE network along with all the other phones in my house
I often get no service or less strong signal strength as others sitting right next to me using the same network
This also impacts the ability to use this phone as a hotspot
While the Wi-Fi connectionbetween the phone and the other device is excellent, the overall usefulness is limited by less than optimal cellular performance
Camera - Just not good
It has comparable specs with higher end phones, but it just does not take good photos, particularly outside
I assume this is a firmware issue and is hopefully something they can correct
Photo quality is OK inside and with a flash, but photos outside on a cloudy day or with any movement the images come out blurry
I could pretty much take photos in the dark with my Lumia and they would turn out

I have kids and take a lot of action photos, so the poor camera quality is a real deal breaker for meScreen -The phone looks fine when it is used inside, but it can be hard to see outside in natural light
I am sure this is one reason for the excellent battery life, but it would be good to trade a little less battery for some additional brightness

Overall Quality/Fit and Finish - Not only can't this phone hold a candle to the Samsung Galaxy and iPhones in my house, is not even on par with my vintage Lumia or even the low end Samsung phones that come with the prepaid plans that my younger kids use
The phone is light and plastic feeling
The buttons feel cheap and the charging port and earphone jacks have more play than you would expect in a new phone
The screen is paper thin and has already cracked after a minor fall from my coat pocket, which my old Lumia survived dozens and dozens of times without a scratch
if you only want to spend a couple hundred bucks and you mainly sit inside and surf the web on a Wi-Fi network and use ear buds, you will like this phone

If you actually need to use this phone in its capacity as a telephone or if you are looking at this as a lower cost option to the high end Samsung or iPhones, you probably are going to be disappointed

Very happy with my Moto
This phone replaced an aging Tracfone LG Ultimate 2 which was a good phone for what it was but had its limitations in terms of operating specs, screen size, camera, etc
I mainly use a smartphone for web browsing, simple games, and camera, and the Moto is light years ahead of the LG in those areas
The other main pluses are 64 GB of internal storage (eliminating the need for an sd card), a much bigger and clearer screen, and a fingerprint scanner
Everything seems to be working flawlessly and smoothly on the phone so far
The only downside to the Moto is the overall size of the unit itself
It is rather long and a bit wide due to the somewhat obtrusive bezels, and when you add a protective case it's even bigger and a bit difficult to pull out of a jeans pocket
It's certainly too big and heavy for a shirt pocket
I should mention that I did have some major heartburn transferring from my old phone to the new one on the Tracfone (Verizon) network
It took nearly two weeks to get the minutes transferred and the phone up and running on the network due to, I'm afraid to say, some shoddy work by the Tracfone customer service reps

Except for the problem I will describe, this would be a five star product and probably is if you don't use Verizon
But Verizon is the biggest carrier and the description says it works with Verizon so it deserves to get a bad review for this problem
If you make or receive calls with enhanced HD voice turned on then very often the other person will hear you fine but you will just hear a garbled voice that is impossible to understand
This is a well documented problem and one that Motorola acknowledges
They say a fix is coming but cannot tell us when that is
In the meantime they say the solution is to turn off enhanced HD voice
That might seem like a simple solution but there are two problems with this
I use a Verizon network extender in order to get service in my house
This does not work without HD voice on

Am I supposed to remember to turn this on and off every time I come or go from my house?If and when this problem is fixed, I would change this to a five star review because it really is a nice phone delivered with no bloatware (assuming you don't get the Amazon ad version)

I was happy to receive the phone so quickly
The happiness slowly went away when I picked up the box and felt that the box inside was bouncing all over
It was the phone box inside a bigger box marked 'prime' on it with nothing to cushion the phone
There were no peanuts or bubbles of any kind to cushion or protect the item from bouncing around
The return label says Amazon Fulfillment Service, 172 Trade Street, Lexington, KY40511
The final destination is Rhode Island
That's a long ways with no real protection and a lot of bouncing around
I took the package out and sure enough things sounded loose in the phone box too
I opened it and the phone was there and one charger, and cord, sim card remover and a useless instruction booklet
It felt like the phone had been opened before or definitely packaged in a hurry
It took a while to finally set it up

I called MOTO directly, as much as they tried to help me, we couldn't get it to work
I will not get another Moto phone for fear it may be a hiccup they need to fix

The only way to remove them without clicking is to remove the battery
The security flaws are a big risk

Don't be tempted with the camera and memory

Everyone else I know have easy removable, replaceable batteries
but not this one!After much internet research and one Youtube video, looks like I not only need to buy a replacement battery, but also a complete set of mini tools

One of the best phones I've ever owned.
Been using the phone for about a week and other than installing a launcher app from the Play Store, this phone is unbelievable
I was skeptical about the fingerprint reader but I was blown away by how quickly it reads the fingerprint
Any owners of a Samsung S6 or S7 knows their fingerprint reader is very temperamental
But it was not the case with this one
Though the specs of this phone don't exactly make it a ''flagship'' phone, it is still an extremely quick and responsive phone
The best way to describe this phone in my opinion is that it's a underrated phone

I have yet to experience any lag whatsoever
The screen is bright and sharp
Battery life is stronger that you would expect
Speaker volume is very loud, both the earpiece speaker and also the speakerphone
Build quality is sturdy and very good
Like I mentioned earlier, I did install a launcher but that's only cause I paid for it and might as well use it
But over time, a user would have no issues getting used to the UI that Huawei uses

I've owned a few phones that were once considered ''flagship'' by their manufacturer, (HTC M7, LG G3, Samsung S6 & S7
I highly recommend this phone to anyone looking for something budget friendly simply because I feel like you're definitely going to get A LOT more than you paid

There is a lot that this phone does well
But there are a couple of things that get into the very annoying region, and a few things that are not a huge deal but unfortunate
Most importantly, the Bluetooth doesn’t work properly for US compatibility

I’ve spent a lot of time with customer service about this (the Huawei US customer service chat is excellent, by the way), with Huawei and with Honda and Panasonic for these respective issues, and I think we’ve determined that there is the US Bluetooth and the Rest Of The World Bluetooth – they don’t necessarily work with each other, and it appears that Huawei uses the Rest Of The World Bluetooth
Now the items that are not a huge deal but unfortunate
All in all, it’s a very good phone, and you can’t beat the price for the features

Charging - No fast charge technology
To sum up, this is a great phone for the price

ORIGINAL REVIEW:11/6/16I wanted to graduate from the outdated smart phones on Tracfones website without losing the service

Phantastic Phone!  Works on GoSmart.  Attracts LEGO people
If you don't want to spend a fortune but aren't willing to sacrifice and buy a bargain phone, all the essential specs are here
Two weeks daily use observations:---The battery life is unbelievable
Super-fantastic and phenomenal even
I can go 2-3 days between charges with normal usage
I've had it on for 32 hours now and it's at 63%
---I really like the power management in this phone
The phone doesn't want anything sucking up juice in the background and it lets you know what's happening right in the pull down notifications
It says Hey knucklehead, you left Angry Birds running in the background (kill button)
It's actually nicer than that
It doesn't call you names but it does constantly make you aware of things you may want to turn off
I love that
---The included one-touch tool for cleaning your useless data from the phone internal memory and SD card is also quite nice
---The GPS response is really fast
I have other devices that take as long as a minute or more to lock on, I have some that are pretty quick (a second or two)
The Honor is as fast or faster than anything I've used
The accuracy seem pretty solid too
---Set up the fingerprint scanner
It's awesome!(I didn't for over a week)Opening up specific apps with a certain finger from sleep mode is actually a useful feature that I may have a hard time going without in the future
I have to keep the phone locked to use this feature (I wish that were optional) but I use code 0000 (simple) and both index fingerprints open it in under a second
One finger opens music, another, my fav GPS app, etc
---I like the included FM receiver
You need to plug in earbuds or a 3
What's also nice is you can swap between listening with the earbuds or using the external speaker
---The more I play with it, the more I like the EMUI interface
I refused to add a more android loader (yet?) as I wanted to give the vanilla interface a real test first
Having no app drawer doesn't really bother me (who knew?)
---So far I am liking this camera
It focuses very well and pictures have been coming out quite nice
I've seen others do better in low lighting but overall, it's a good camera
The perfect selfie makes me look 20 years younger if set to 10
---The screen is really vibrant
It has whites that are actually white and fairly deep blacks
---On a more Android related note, I hear that there's already a working TWRP for this phone and they are working on a version of Cyanogenmod for it
Tempered glass feels great on here, possibly more responsive!(?)FYI - I hooked mine up to the $30/month, 4GB data, GoSmart Mobile plan in Seattle area
Data seems fine to me but I don't use a huge amount
It's new, and I suspect more cases will come if we keep buying this phone
---It isn't playing well with my smartwatch (Moto 360, 1st Gen)
I can't seem to get weather pushed onto it and some other annoyances (worked perfect with my Galaxy S3)
Will keep trying
I'll find a different watch before I dump this phone
It's too low and feels awkward to reach with an index finger (the finger Samsung has trained me to use)
The fingerprint unlock circumvents this particular annoyance
There's very few phones that match what this is at this price point
The Asus Zen Phone 2 is nice too at a similar price, but the little extras here were hard to pass up
I'd buy this again without hesitation

Best bang for the buck!
I did a lot of research on various full featured Android phones, and I about had a heart attack to see what they were going for
Trying to to find the best bang for the buck, I was pleasantly surprised to find this Honor 5x Unlocked Smart Phone rated almost as well as the big name phones, but at a modest price

I was pleased to see that it possessed an 8 core processor that runs at quite a decent processor speed, that the camera quality, sound quality, screen size and resolution were all quite respectable as well
Then I saw that it possessed the second to last Android version (Lollipop) of software
It was also an Unlocked GSM phone (I have T-Mobile)
It truly measures up to what all was said about it in the press
And if it does happen to get broken or stolen, it won't be nearly as financially painful to you

Bad headphone jack, bad Huawei service
The Honor 5X is a pretty phone, but lacks durability
I got this phone for my 15 year old son in April 2017
He uses it daily, protects it with a Spigen Rugged Armor case, and has not subjected it to any mistreatment
In October, he reported that the headphone jack no longer worked
I started a warranty return claim online with Huawei
Before they issued me a packing slip, Huawei required me to send them 6 photos of the phone (from all angles)
After 3 days, the phone was delivered back unrepaired
O RLY? I checked with my son, who said he did not expose the phone to water
I called Huawei and got a very obliging and apologetic person on the phone who was sweet as can be, and said that he would escalate the case
I then got an email from Huawei repeating that examination of the phone showed liquid damage that voided the warranty
The only liquid that might have touched the phone was a few raindrops
My overall takeaway from this experience: this phone is not durable enough for everyday use
My son's buying himself an iPhone now
And I will never again purchase anything made by Huawei, no matter how shiny or cheap
